It has to be the mildest razor I have ever used. I really don't think you could cut yourself if you tried to. I have many more expensive razors and bought this one for a travel razor. It is that and much more. Sure it won't last forever like a gillette but it is so cheap you can replace it easy if it wears out or is lost. You really can't go wrong with this razor.
  8. Just like the old days, close shave with only the inexpensive blades to dispose of. This Razor is a metal and plastic copy of the old twist to open Razors. Closer shave than disposables but takes a little more time as the blades are sharp and if you have never used this style razor it takes awhile to learn technique. Since I am an old geezer it was a breeze to transition.
  9. Very pleased with this razor. I had given up on shaving after decades of infections and painful skin irritation until I was tired of the beard and had to do something. A little research (20 years too late) and I realized the problem was probably ingrown hairs from razors that were far too aggressive for my face.<br /><br />The razor feels well built and not flimsy. Considering others in this category cost several times as much, I wasn't expecting a whole lot. Well, I can say my face has never been happier!<br /><br />This razor is NOT aggressive. It barely feela like it is doing anything and sometimes i will shave twice, using different directions. With the multiblade razors, I could go for two or more days without shaving and almost get away with it. If you have 5 o'clock shadow with a multiblade disposable, I would guess this isn't the razor for you. I now need to shave every day but that is fine since I'm also free from the pain and discomfort.<br /><br />If you don't have irritation or skin problems from your current disposable I don't think it makes sense to even try this model. You will be shaving all the time.<br /><br />Last thought on the safety razors- I definitely am nicking myself more but getting better at it. Take your time. I can't imagine what a more aggressive razor would be like. And, read up on the subject if you've never used one of these. Lots of good shaving information (and opinion) on the web.
  10. No, it's not me. I was bleeding a lot so I purchased a vintage Gillette Flare Tip... for half the price of this item... and haven't cut myself on it yet and it's been about 2 months. The handle on the Feather is too long for me and it lacks a good balance. The Gillette is perfect... nice weight and a short handle helps me keep the correct angle for shaving. I use Derby Extra [[ASIN:B004SGKMA0 Derby Extra Double Edge Razor Blades, 100 Count]] and Astra Superior [[ASIN:B001QY8QXM 100 Astra Superior Premium Platinum Double Edge Safety Razor Blades]] blades in both so that wasn't the problem. This is a nice razor overall so that would get it 5-stars but since I was making a blood sacrifice using it gets 3-stars based on how it worked for me... who knows, perhaps it was made on a Friday and doesn't meet the standards of what others are using.
  11. Great shave for an excellent value. I owned one of these a few years back, which only broke after a couple years, so well worth the $18.
  12. I wasn't a complete newbie buying this razor, as I had used an ancient Gillette butterfly previously until the opening mechanism permanently locked up, but this required some getting used to. The head is massive compared to modern razors and the plastic is a little off putting at first. However, the overall weight is good and you start to appreciate the superior grip of the plastic handle as opposed to a metal one.<br /><br />Once you get the cutting angle right and figure out the correct amount of pressure, it cuts very nicely. Unfortunately, I'm getting nicked on my neck no matter how careful I am. I guess that's just a trade off to using the technology.<br /><br />I was concerned about the quality considering there are other German made razors that proudly tout their teutonic superiority. Turns out I didn't have to worry. The packaging says made in Japan, which while not German quality, is pretty good.

  14. I'm 34 and like many guys my age, I was sent a Gillette razor in the mail when I turned 18 (I think they had just introduced the Mach 3). So for the past 15 years I have spent ungodly amounts of money on the latest \\"breakthrough\\" in razor technology as well as the crazily priced blades. The whole time I have had issues with shaving that we all have experienced. Irritation, razor burns, and not close enough shaves. Recently a friend of mine Said he had switched to an old fashioned safety razor. I figured I would try it out so I found this Feather razor for under $20 and figured what the hell, I spend that on replacement blades. I have been using the Feather for about a week now and I couldn't be more happy with the results. It took a day or two to get used to and to refine my technique but now it is easily the best shave I have ever had. Extremely close and virtually no irritation at all. I also have yet to cut myself because you are basically forced to go slow and pay more attention. This is an awesome product and I highly recommend it.
  15. I bought this Feather Popular razor after reading a few reviews and watching a couple of videos on youtube. I also bought an Edwin Jagger DE89bl at the same time of purchase because my first Edwin Jagger broke where the stud screws into the shaft. I must say I was used to using the Edwin Jagger which I have been shaving with for a few years now and really liked it. Here enters the Feather Popular. My first pass I thought it wasn't cutting any whiskers but in fact it was, it's just that coupled with the Feather blades it slices right through them. This razor is made of a plastic handle and a metal twist to open top piece. You would think with the price it would be of cheap quality but it's made in Japan with the Japanese quality you would expect. This razor is not as aggressive as my Edwin Jagger DE89bl but gets the job done well. I would highly recommend this to the beginner single double edge blade wet shaver because it's so forgiving. I would even recommend this the more experienced shaver just to change things up. This will be the razor of my choice to travel with which comes with a travel case. Saving up for the Stainless Steel Feather.

  32. shaved off piece of meat
  33. The Feather \\"Popular\\" twist-to-open (TTO) razor is a good entry-level product for those interested in trying out traditional shaving. There are other currently manufactured TTO razors on the market, but the quality is generally hit or miss. Despite the light weight and partial plastic construction, in many ways this is better than razors from Parker that cost the same or more. The best feature of this razor in my opinion is the more sloped profile of the cutting head. The vintage safety razors from Gillette had a head like this, before they moved to a more \\"slim\\" profile in the early 1960's, ostensibly making it easier to shave the tight areas under the nose. But in keeping this \\"fatter\\" head, the Feather Popular is a very good choice for those with sensitive skin, since it requires a less-steep blade angle. The drawback to this, combined with the razor's overall light weight, is that the shave is very mild. But if paired with a very sharp blade like Feathers (probably the sharpest blades currently available by some stretch), it's possible to get a close, smooth shave with no irritation. And it's also worth noting that blade alignment in the cutting head is even on both sides. You'd think this goes without saying, but you'd be surprised at how many modern TTO's don't get this right. The blade is also locked securely in place. However, given the Feather company's high standards, I have to wonder why 85% of the razor is plastic, including the entire lower portion of the cutting head. This affects the razor's glide a bit and shaving cream/soap scum is more noticeable on the black plastic over time. But that's more of a cosmetic concern and it doesn't mean the razor is \\"cheap\\" by any means. This is something that will probably last on the order of 50 years with proper care. And with 6 to 7 shaves per blade, with less irritation than modern cartridge systems, it's a smart choice for men who are curious about wetshaving. I still think the Lord L6 razor (also available on Amazon) is the best choice for a cheap starter razor, but you could certainly do worse than the Feather Popular.
  34. I think I found my new favourite razor.
  35. Switched to a safety razor and loving it. Replacements are so much cheaper and much sharper than the disposable ones. Single blade keeps the shave smooth. Materials are high quality and have a nice weight.
  36. Great razor and a very good shave. This is the low end of the feather razor's but it is a very good one. Not aggressive at all and not to mild. It is just right for the average beard. Heavy beards may find this not as aggressive enough for them but for me it is just right.Thank you very much.
  37. Bought this for my fiance, he likes it.
  38. works as its supposed to, bought due to the price of all the other razors being expensive. Econimcal blades.
  39. This was my first Double-Edge razor purchase.<br /><br />The razor is light, but sturdy. The twist to open mechanism holds the blade in place in a very sturdy way. You will never question if it's going to loosen up in use.<br /><br />The blades that come with this razor are possibly the sharpest razor blades available on the market. If you're learning how to use a double edge razor; you should order other blades. If you don't your face is going to be absolutely destroyed. Nicks, scrapes, blood and irritation everywhere.<br /><br />If you're new to shaving with these kinds of razors, or you're looking for a cheap travel razor. The little dude is great.

But the places I did not cut myself, my face is as smooth as a new born babies behind. There is no pulling of hair, it cuts it nicely. I am sure with practice, this will be the razor i have used.<br /><br />A fast tip, make sure your water is hot... That will soften every thing up for you. I used Barbersol and it did well, but I will get soap and a brush and try that.<br /><br />I am glad I got this razor. Like i said, I cannot compare to a better quality razor, but this one seemed sturdy and well made.<br /><br />BTW, did I mention it gives a smooth shave?
  42. Great razor for the price
  43. After reading reviews and articles about how double edge razors have improved and are so much cheaper to use than Gillette's Fusion and similar - I decided to give it a try. I have a thick beard and have been able to grow a beard from age 14 on. I am always looking for a better way to get a shave - and if it saves money - that's a bonus. When it comes to shaving, the blades are the most important part, then the razor and then the shaving cream. This was the best double edger razor I tried. Unfortunately for me, even with the best blades I could find - a double edge razor just doesn't cut my beard. I'm still supporting Gillette. BTW, you can significantly increase the life a any blade by rinsing and drying them when you are finished.
  44. After years of wasting money on virtually all the modern, high-tech razors, I decided to do some research into double edged safety razors. The reviews on Amazon were very helpful. I made my decision to buy this \\"Feather\\" based on several of the reviews. I'm glad I did. I forgot what a pleasure using a DE razor is, and after several weeks, I've only had only a couple of minor knicks. You need to pay attention to what you are doing. The trick is not to use any pressure or force. I liked the Feather razor blades so much I ended up ordering 100 of them. I am getting the best shave I've had in years with this combination.
  45. This is for my money the best DE razor on the market! For 21.95 or for 100 dollars- this razor is just spectacular especially with the feather razor blades. Shaves as comfortably as a multi blade- no cuts or nicks- but it shaves off all the hair in two or maybe three passes. Great head angle- allows you to use a little more pressure than you might actually need without too much danger of nicks or cuts. I personally put it above the Lord L6 because it is made better and has the butterfly head. This razor is just a pleasure to shave with! And I am sticking too it!
  46. This was my first safety razor and first time ever trying one. I also used a nice shaving cream brush before shaving.. Took a few trys to get the right angle but once I did it shaved very nicely I did short small strokes and it left my face very smooth with no cuts just make sure you shave with the grain. I felt it took the same amount of time to shave as a 5 blade razor and I don't feel any razor burn... I'm looking forward to using thus razor alot more. It's very hard to cut yourself with this razor
  47. This is not built like jewelry (Edwin Jagger), nor does it have a fine industrial tool look to it (Merkur). Once you get past the plastic/resin look and shave with it, you will be pleasantly surprised. A word of caution: don't initially use the included Feather blade with it. Use your normal blade. This will provide the best way to evaluate just the razor. I got a great shave with it. It turns out that the long handle has a nice balance to it. It would make a fine travel or gym razor, a good introductory DE safety razor, and even a decent gift. The performance is quite good. April 15, 2015 Update I have other razors (Edwin Jagger and Merkur) and I am pleasantly surprised to say that I get my best shave from this razor. I don't find the plastic to be a drawback in any way. The razor is easy to use, holds the blade in a consistent alignment, and feels great on my hand. I am going to buy 2 more: one for me and one for my nephew. July 1, 2016 Still the best shave out of all my razors, including the great Gillette razors from the 1950s and 1960s. It is easy to handle and almost impossible to get a bad shave. I can shave with this razor with a Feather or Astra blade and literally never nick myself.
  48. My husband really likes this razor. He is an ole fashion kinda guy....doesn't care for all the latest and greatest razors. He is enjoying this very much, so glad you guys had it.
  49. This is the perfect razor to use for transitioning from the multibladed, overpriced offerings into the single bladed shave world. The lightness & length of the handle helps prevent nicking for the first-time user as well as provides a familiar feel when shaving. The feather blades are extremely sharp and gives as close of a shave as the multiblade cartridges. I am getting to the point of moving to an all-metal razor as I have found that I am pressing too hard on certain areas of my face, which increases the chance of nicks. The heavier handle weight should provide the closeness without using undue pressure. This razor will then go into my travel kit. All-in-all, I am very pleased with this razor, and my wallet is thankful as well!
  50. I decided to give the straight razor thing a shot after hearing the internet sing its praises. I bought it for shaving my legs and armpits, not face, so keep that in mind while reading this.<br /><br />The razor comes in a nice plastic case that also holds a pack of blades. The top opens in a really neat and convenient way to allow easy placement of the blades. I can't imagine how someone could mess up inserting a blade.<br /><br />I bought shave lotion, as opposed to cream, to use with this so it would glide smoother since it's easier to hurt yourself with a straight razor vs a &#34;normal&#34; one. I also exfoliated and did every preparatory step possible to get this to work properly.<br /><br />I went slowly and carefully while shaving my underarms and it worked great. However, my legs were a different story. Even though I went slow and steady, I cut myself about 5 times on my legs when I first used this. I figured I was just ignorant to the finer points of straight razors so decided to try again in a few days. Lo and behold, I flayed my legs again.<br /><br />This razor may be great for beards, I have no idea though. I do know it works well for underarms but would suggest maybe not using it for your legs. There's just too many curves and bumps and lumps around the ankles and knees to use one of these effectively without cutting yourself up.
  51. This is my 3rd de razor. Was actually hoping for something in between my edwin jagger and Van der hagen. This one compares almost identical the the Van der hagen as far as aggressiveness. It is a very mild mannered, non aggressive razor. Almost impossible to cut yourself even with a feather blade. This razor provides a great shave with a 2nd pass. The extra long plastic handle gives a good feel in my hand. Easy to grip and maneuver. Plastic makes it a lightweight, which I like. I know with the heavy razors you are supposed to let the weight apply the pressure. I prefer to apply the pressure myself, just my personal liking. This razor washes clean easy without plugging. Positions the blade nice and even.
  52. This is my first DE razor and it's a good, moderately priced one.<br /><br />I've officially been converted to DE shaving! :-)
  53. Simple double-edge razor that works well and within my budget.
  54. After a fair bit of research on double edged (DE) safety razors I decided on the Feather Popular razor. As I'm sure you have by now, I did a lot of reading up on the practice of DE shaving. I wasn't sure what I was exactly getting into, so I didn't want to lay out a huge amount of money. The price, combined with the positive reviews (here and elsewhere), were the primary factors that drove me to purchase this razor.<br /><br />Honestly, the razor itself, in construction and materials, doesn't entirely justify the cost at about $22.00 to me. Some of that is certainly due to it' packaging, which includes a plastic case (suitable for travel). While this is by far on the low end of the spectrum on DE razor pricing, I feel a more fair price for this product might be around $15. That said, I would buy this razor again at $22.<br /><br />If you look at the image on the product page, what you see as the black parts of the razor are plastic. It's light in weight (seemed lighter than the 3-blade cartridge system I had been using) but the plastic doesn't feel cheap. What you see as the sliver parts of the razor are stainless steel.<br /><br />The action of the TTO (twist to open) mechanism feels a little loose when open, but I found that once a blade was loaded, and the mechanism was closed, it held the blade very securely, and dead-on straight with the razor's protective guard.<br /><br />With the razor in place, I found the fully assembled device was very nice to shave with. I used [[ASIN:B001JHEY14 Proraso Shaving Soap, Ultra Sensitive Skin]] applied with a [[ASIN:B000G647Y8 Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush]], with the included Feather blade (2). I have just one shave completed with this razor, but the experience was very much like shaving with my previous 3-blade cartridge system, although far superior in removing the 5 days' growth of my thick whiskers.<br /><br />A lower price would certainly have gotten 5 stars out of me for this review. This is a very nice product, I would buy it again, and would certainly recommend it to a friend.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Fantastic \\"my-first-DE-razor\\"<br />Straight and secure blade retention<br />Comes with a case and blades<br /><br />Cons:<br />(and this a pretty minor one) Could potentially be a little less expensive

I went online and watched a few videos as to not slice my face apart, and after setting everything up, I was shaving away! The blades are quite sharp, and the handle is sturdy. Like others, I too was worried that this item was plastic, but this is a solid handle in my opinion. I now use this for shaving, and don't plan to go back to a cartridge razor if I can help it.   62. I've tried several different safety razors and this is one of the very best. The only razor I like better is also made by Feather and cost $175. For the money this is the best razor I know about. It gives a close mild shave without producing irritation. It is made of a lightweight stainless steel head and some sort of very lightweight plastic/polymer handle. It is not low quality and I think it would hold up to years of daily use. Since I broke down and bought the high-priced Feather DS-A2, this has become my travel razor. If you want great shaving on a shoe string, you can't beat this razor. Paired up with Van Der Hagen Natural Boar Shave Brush, Arko Shave Soap and Feather Hi-Stainless Platimum Double Edge Razor Blades 50 Ct you could shave for at least a year for about $50. The quality of the shave is far superior to multi-blade disposable razors or any electric razor I've ever tried.
  63. I switched from Mach 3 to this DE razor. It is incredible. The blades are razor sharp and you simply wet your face up real good after a shower with hot water. Take a badger hair shaving brush, wet it, and rub it around in something like [Proraso Shaving Soap, Eucalyptus & Menthol - $5 bucks here]. Spread it all over your beard generously and shave using the weight of the razor to cut. Wet it frequently under hot water. Use the brush to relather if you need to and keep everything wet. You will be a pro at WETSHAVING in no time and will never switched back to those lousy old carts. You can buy 100 blades for 10 backs and shave for years. BECOME A MAN.

  65. This a a beautiful razor at a reasonable price. Well constructed with a moderate blade exposure that is not too aggressive but does a good job. If you have ever struggled with changing the blade in a three-piece DE razor then you will love the clam-shell design of this razor. It is light in the hand but has good balance. The handle is long enough to feel comfortable in the hand. Some purists complain about the use of plastic in this razor but there is nothing inherently wrong with the use of quality plastics. Is this a 'classic' razor to be passed down the generations? Probably not, but it appears to be a good razor that will provide long service.

  75. I'm a woman and first time user of a safety razor. I didn't want to spend a lot on one in case I hated using it, so I went with this affordable Feather. It comes in a plastic case with two Feather brand blades. Putting the blade in it is super easy, you just twist the handle and it flops open, you place the blade in, then twist the handle again to close it. It is made of very cheap metal and plastic. I see this rusting and falling apart quickly. But again this was perfect for a first timer that doesn't want to spend a lot of money.<br /><br />Oh and it shaved my legs like a charm, I had to be slower and more careful but I didn't cut myself once and I got a really close shave. I was told to not start off with the Feather brand blades though as they are very very sharp, it is recommended that you work your way up to Feather brand blades (but that was just one man's opinion).
  76. I started thinking about a safety razor a few months ago because of the high price of replacement cartridges. It is surprisingly hard to find a safety razor at a store, so I searched on Amazon, I almost settled on a cheaper razor than this one, After reading the reviews on them, however, I chose this one instead. One of the things the reviews said of the cheaper one was that the blade was loose, and wasn't even when put into the razor. I am very happy I chose this one! I didn't want to spend a lot, since I had never used one. I used it for the first time this morning, expecting a few cuts while learning. No cuts, but I do have minor razor burn. I think this can be avoided next time by getting a good shaving soap. The razor itself is very well made, easy to clean, inexpensive, and replacement blades are very affordable. I give it five stars because of value and how well it is made. Can't think of anything bad to say about it at all.

  90. I shave in the shower and this razor is absolutely perfect for that. Don't worry about the polymer either. You can't get anything better for a wet environment. The butterfly mechanism works smoothly and cleans easily. The handle is as long as my Parker long handle razor, but the razor is obviously much lighter. I have a heavy beard and the wife can't stand any stubble. The included Feather blade has blown me away! I have gotten two shaves a day for seven days. There is no pulling or tugging with this blade, just once with the grain, once against the grain and once sideways on those stubborn neck hairs and my face is baby butt smooth. I tried the blade in the Parker, but got a closer shave with the Feather razor. If you are new to DE shaving, I would recommend a different blade until your face and beard get used to the difference from the disposables. All it takes with DE blades is good lather and a light touch. I won't shave with anything but a Feather from now on. I haven't had a shave like this since I was a teenager using my old Gillette. I very highly recommend both the razor and the blades.

  93. Don't let the critics steer you away from this razor. The packaging and graphics look like cheap junk from a discount store, but Feather blades are awesome. The company dominates the medical/surgical market, so they know how to make sharp and dependable blades. They just don't comprehend our association of that labeling art style with inferior product.<br />The razor has a plastic handle, but so what? It's a tool for shaving, not a prized heirloom to show off and brag about. It is lightweight, but to me that's a plus, giving better control around the chin and adam's apple.<br />Alignment is good, blade fits perfectly on the metal center rib. Blade exposure is perfect for shaving. The critics who claim it isn't enough for a close shave want a straight razor, not a safety razor., The mechanism is smooth and secure. The top opens by twisting the metal ring at the top of the handle, so it won't loosen up by accident while shaving, but still opens easily to rinse or change blades. Cheaper than disposables, shaves better, and doesn't clog up like multi-blades.<br />I'll quit shaving before I go back to twin blades or disposables.

  110. Feather makes some of the best Razor Blades I've ever used, so I had high hopes for this razor. And I wasn't disappointed! I've only been using it for about a week, but it works just as well as I had hoped. The butterfly 'doors' operate smoothly and hold the blade securely at an angle that is not overly aggressive. On the con side, the plastic handle makes the razor feel a bit light and cheap, as well as giving it an awkward balance compared to my Merkur Futur. And they only included two blades! But really, for the price, I don't think you will find a better razor, and any fan of DE shaving who is on a budget would be well served by this piece. UPDATE: Unfortunately my Feather DE razor suffered a catastrophic failure when I dropped it in the bathroom. The plastic bit holding the head to the handle broke. I will likely purchase another at some point, it really is a good value.

  117. I used a Parker for about 3 years until it finally broke. It was heavy and I was frequently nicking myself no matter how careful I was. I used Feather blades, not realizing that Feather actually made a razor as well. Unlike the more expensive Parker, the blade fits perfectly into the razor so it's even on both sides. I've been using it for 3 months and have nicked myself only once and this is because I was in a hurry. I liked it so much that I decided to buy one for my daughter. I was a little apprehensive because she is only seventeen and fairly new to shaving. After she had used it a few times, I asked her if she had had any trouble with cutting herself. She said no and that, not only was she shaving nick free, but that it was &#34;a thousand times better&#34; than the cartridge type she had been using before. So men, don't just buy one for yourself, get one for the women in your life as well.
  118. It's cheaper than the all-metal version, which concerned me at first when finding a safety razor to buy. However, now that I've used it for a couple months, I can see that the concern was misplaced. This instrument is very high quality (even considering it's mostly plastic). They've weighted the shaving end (just like more expensive razors) so no direct pressure is needed when shaving. Just let the weight of this razor fall against your skin and you'll get a close shave. The three reasons I switched from my Mach 3 to this? First, the Mach 3 cartridges were insanely expensive (as I'm sure you know). Second, I have really sensitive skin and the single blade really lessens the irritation (a single-blade shaver was recommended by my dermatologist for this reason...more blades equates to more potential irritation). Third, it's manly and bad ass.
  119. Although it is plastic, it works smoothly, centers the razor perfectly, and is easy to use. I wish I could give it a 4.5 because my only qualm, which is very small, is that this razor is not aggressive enough to take full advantage of Feather Razor blade sharpness. Thus it would be a five star for a new user.
  120. I luv this razor because it's stylish & it cost a $1 too replace da blade..shaving is real smooth on my skin. Bye Bye 2 all da other razors that wants u 2 pay $15 or more 2 replace da blades
  121. This is a nice DE razor. I own a Merkur HD 180 and this Feather handle. The feather is surprisingly less aggressive than the 180. This is a good thing for me, since I'm just learning. If you're on the fence about 3 piece, 2 piece, or this 1 piece design, it really doesn't matter. I like the Merkur because I can take it completely apart to dry. The feather is also good because it only requires a twist to change blades. No matter what, you're going to have to handle the blade with you're fingers to change them, so one is not actually safer than the other. I alternate shaving between the 180 and the feather. I keep coming back to the feather because it shaves less aggressively, and shaves cleanly without as much irritation. I've never used any other blade in this feather razor besides feather's own blades. I will say about the feather blades that you have to shave with good form, because these blades cut very well! Feather's own brand for razor and blade really are a perfect match. Other blades that I have tried are Astra SP and Sharks Super Chrome. And those shave well too, and are not as likely to cause cuts you didn't realize as the feather blades. However, I use those with the Merkur. What I did was buy both astras and feathers packs of blades, because I like both of those very much.<br />Here's how I got into DE shaving. I'm coming from Gillette fusion pro glide! I was searching for some shaving cream other than the canned stuff, and somehow in my search, got turned to the world of classic shaving. I can say that the DE is a superior shave to the cartridges. The blades are extremely sharp, so care has to be taken when switching to a DE. Overall, I've gotten much closer shaves and I actually shave more often now! Just take your time and use very very little pressure or none at all, and you will see how incredible real razors are!
  122. saves money on razors. no need to fill the landfill with disposable plastic razors. the refill is like a dollar for like ten or twenty at walmart. the feather razors are of superior quality though. i think its the japanese steel.
  123. At first I thought I forgot to put a blade in it, so smooth; maybe not as close a shave as some, but well worth it
  124. This razor is my second. After first purchasing an [[ASIN:B002QTX8WU Edwin Jagger Double Edge (DE) Safety Razor - Lined Chrome Handle]], because of the good review for that -- and the nice chrome finish -- I found it to be too aggressive and was not satisfied using Astra and Feather blades. I found it to be irritating, so I wanted to try something else. This Feather razor is fantastic! I can use just about any blade and get a close and comfortable shave, without irritation. It makes shaving a lot easier. I think many of those people who claim that you have to have a great technique to not cut yourself with the sharp Feather blades are simply using the wrong razors. [[ASIN:B0022R947O Feather Hi-Stainless Platimum Double Edge Razor Blades]], [[ASIN:B001QY8QXM Astra Superior Premium Platinum Double Edge Safety Razor Blades]], and other blades work wonderfully for me with this razor.
  125. I was hoping for a better experience with this. I have been a \\"straight razor\\" shaver for many years, so I know a thing or two about these double sided blades and all. For some reason though I just can't stop cutting the crap out of my neck, and it just doesn't shave all that smoothly even on my cheeks. Maybe it's my form, I dunno, but I'll keep giving it a chance and possibly update a while down the road.<br /><br />Update: I rarely shave my face these days- working on a bitchin' beard, but I still do my upper cheeks and neck. When the neck hair is still relatively short, I find a pre-shower dry shave with this unit to be just right. It still isn't amazingly close, and that is probably just what I get for buying a cheap-o handle, but it is good enough for most situations. One word of caution though- don't be lazy, use a fresh blade.
  126. \\"I know it is customary that to vote not helpful for those reviews that are rated lower by those buyers who actually like the item and rated for ti higher. Therefore, I do not expect to my reviewed to be voted as helpful. This has almost become a norm at Amazon\\".<br /><br />Review...<br />Ordered this item simply because of high ratings on the brand. Feather brand supposed to be the best of razors out there...I also decided to give a try the old fashion razor to replace my modern 5 blade Schick just for nostalgic and coolness purposes. I was not sure of the expectations. Based on reviews however, I really tough that these razors, especially this brand, both the blade and the razor would be superior to my 5 blade Schick. I was not really concerned about the cost but functionality and style. .<br /><br />One thing concerned me was that the fact that many reviewers warned that first shave would be bloody hell.<br /><br />My order came in 2 days with my Prime membership. Item was well packed, and Made in Japan, very good quality razor. Package had 5 blades also.<br />Based on reviews, with my concerns, I tried it with care to avoid cutting myself...However, the razor was as smooth as it can get. Not a single drop of blood. So, unlike many reviewers, this razor is very safe.<br /><br />Unfortunately, quality of shaving was very disappointing. Despite several runs over the face, the razor left my face desired to be shaved again with the 5 blade razor. Believenit or not, right after the shave, I had 5 pm shadow.<br /><br />Despite the smooth shave, the razor failed to give me the close shave I use to get from my 5 blade modern Schick.<br /><br />Perhaps since I have a smooth facial hair, this did not work for me..So, despite its failing, instead of 1 start I am giving 3 start to this item, hoping that as reviewed by other, this thing actually works for some..It did not work for me..<br /><br />Now i see that, when it comes to shaving, there is no reason to be nostalgic. It is your face you are dealing with, there is a reason to have 5 blades in new razors, upper blades pull down the hair for the lower blades to cut below the surface level hair giving you a very clean and deep shaving. At least, that is what I believe.<br /><br />Sorry guys..My verdict is; Don't Buy !It is your face you are dealing with, there is a reason to have 5 blades in new razors, upper blades pull down the hair for the lower blades to cut below the surface level hair giving you a very clean and deep shaving. At least, that is what I believe.<br /><br />Sorry guys..My verdict is; Don't Buy !
  127. Before anyone decides to purchase this, please consider one thing. You get what you paid for. I like this razor. It's a butterfly opening which makes it safer to load the blade and also easier. The handle might be a plastic, but the top is heavy enough to apply right amount of pressure to your face, which makes it easier to shave. It's got grids for better gripping, which i had trouble with razors without any grids for gripping. However the expose of the blade is very small and i have to do more touch ups for that BSS (Baby Smooth Shave). I even used the feather blade and still had stubbles at the end. I can still feel it around my chin, which i had no problem with my Edwin Jagger DE89. Does that mean it's a bad razor? NOT AT ALL~!! it's actually an excellent razor for starters who are looking for a milder shave that doesn't leave razor burn on their face. From that point on, they can purchase other DE razors that are more aggressive. I only gave it 4 stars, because of it only comes with 2 feather razor blades. It would've been better if they came with at least 5 blades. I know the description says 2 blades, but still the company should include at least 3 more blades to make a better value for the consumers. It'd definitely increase the marginal benefits.
  128. (UPDATE: I've been using this razor for just over two months now and it is the best razor I've owned. It's just like the old Gillette G1000 with the Super Speed head, a slight tad more aggressive but not that you'll notice; your angle will be about the same and finding the best angle for your face is easy. It's an easy shave and a damned close shave. Best for men with light to medium/medium-heavy beards. Heavy beards might like it? Great first time razor and great daily shave for old experienced wet shavers. Buy this razor and you won't regret it.)<br />I just bought this razor for $20.00 that came in a plastic case and a pack of Feather blades (like all razors used to come) and I was completely shocked at how good a razor this is. It shaves exactly like my 1970 Gillette G1000 (was called the Gillette Knack between 1967 - 70)which was famous for a great close razor-burn free shave with one difference: This is a better made razor. Perfect balance, perfect lenght, and the TTO at the top of the razor is bigger and easier to open than the old Gillette. I love this razor!<br />As to the complaints from some about it being a \\"plastic razor\\"...So? My Glock .45 has a forged steel slide that blows back to eject a spent shell by using the energy from firing a 230 grain .45 round on a polymer frame and after over 1000 rounds fired the \\"plastic\\" frame is still just fine. Don't knock this razor for the use of a polymer base and handle, If taken care of it will last as long as a plated brass razor. The head is stainless steel as is the TTO dial and being made by a company that for over three decades has made some of the best surgical instruments for eye and nerve surgery in the world, I'm glad they decided to branch into the shaving business as a side line.<br />This is not an aggressive razor but is just a little more aggressive than the old Gillette Super Speed. Again, it shaves like the G1000 or like the Schick Krona from the 1960's. You'll only notice the difference in the quality of shave you get. If you have a light or medium beard you'll love this razor as it is almost completely nick and cut free; if you (like me) have a heavy beard: 3 - or - 4 way shave time without razor burn. Like the old Gillette or Schick Krona the secret is don't press the blade into your face, let the razor do the work, first with the grain of your beard then however you do your second approach. Bought my son one of these and he has a medium beard and all he does is a one time pass with little touch ups on the left over stubble as he goes.<br />A well made razor at a good price made by a surgical supply company? You can't go wrong.he quality of shave you get. If you have a light or medium beard you'll love this razor as it is almost completely nick and cut free; if you (like me) have a heavy beard: 3 - or - 4 way shave time without razor burn. Like the old Gillette or Schick Krona the secret is don't press the blade into your face, let the razor do the work, first with the grain of your beard then however you do your second approach. Bought my son one of these and he has a medium beard and all he does is a one time pass with little touch ups on the left over stubble as he goes.<br />A well made razor at a good price made by a surgical supply company? You can't go wrong.

  155. Some months ago I was informed about the unparalleled quality of the [[ASIN:B005G2CJ6K Feather Blades]]. So it was only natural to seek out the appropriate Double Edge safety razor to yield them.<br /><br />Outside Japan there are only two models of FEATHER safety razors, this Popular one and the much more expensive [[ASIN:B004E5GV82 All-Stainless Steel one]]. I decided to start with this one and move up in the near future if I was satisfied. And was I ever!<br /><br />The design is streamlined simplicity. On top of a sturdy plastic-covered handle sits a stainless steel head that opens with a twist to receive the double edge blade. The mechanism is precise and works with clockwork perfection both dry and wet.<br /><br />The touching edge guarding the blade's cutting edge is also plastic - a design detail that I was apprehensive of at first. However, once I tried it I appreciated how much more aware I was of the blade's cutting edge and how easier it is to control it.<br /><br />A quality product at a very fair price.<br /><br />HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

  179. Several months ago after experiencing a bad rash on my neck, which was made worse by shaving, I elected to try a different razor type. I went with the double edge Lord L6. I liked the shave but not the razor. It was rather cumbersome to remove/replace the blade. I ended up going on the auction site and I obtained a few old Gillette's. My first one was from the 40's. I loved it. Ended up buying a Fat boy, Black Beauty and Slim boy. All great razors. Each requiring a slightly different technique due to their size and weight. Then I stumbled across this thing. Although inexpensive (not cheap), it in many ways offers the best of the above mentioned razors. The handle is thick like the fat boy making for easy holding, it has a long handle and great styling like the black beauty, but still is very light weight like a disposable. I don't think the light weight aspect can be addressed strongly enough. With a really sharp blade like the feather, you need a very light touch. When you have a heavy razor, it's easy to bear down harder than you should , and inadvertently nick your self. This razor makes that less likely. At first I was really disappointed in this razor. I thought it was cheap , particularly seeing the inside made of plastic, and didn't believe it would last very long. What I previously viewed as a shortcoming I now see as a very distinct advantage. Although I enjoy using the old Gillettes, whenever I come back to this razor I always find myself more impressed by it. A few notes on other things. I found a better price on the auction sites for feather blades, particularly in lots of 100. Although I love the sharpness, the feather blade is very unforgiving. If your skin is not smooth it will remove anything in it's path, hence the need for a VERY light touch. I am considering trying Astra blades, which may not be quite so lethal. It's important to wash your face well before adding any shaving cream or soap. Apply a good aftershave afterwardsto clean up any small nicks you have, then a good skin cream such as Cetaphil moisturizing lotion. As someone with very sensitive skin, I'm forced to pay a bit more attention to these details, and hope perhaps this helps others in the same boat.Likewise I appreciate your tips. Update: 2/26/13 Love love love this razor. I've gotten used to the feather blades, or my skin has just had all the high spots shaved off. IN any case I almost never get a nick anymore. The lightness of the razor , really allows a lot more control than my old Gillette's. Still impressed. I would give this 5 stars now if I could change it. Update 7/1/2016 Still using the original razor, although I did buy a spare about a year or so ago. Sometimes when I travel I take a disposable double edge razor. When I come home I really appreciate the great shave I get with the feather. Now I can change the review to 5 stars and did so.
  180. I just received the Feather and decided to try it out. I've been using the Gillette Mach 3 for many years and prior to that the other newer Gillette double and triple blade systems. Being in my 60's I used the older double edge systems for a few decades. Back then I used Wilkerson Swords. I would shave at least 6 days a week and did so for decades. So my review is based on lots of experience with both systems.<br />Cutting to the chase the Feather is a very good blade, the shaver is ok, but, don't match up to my old chrome heavy weight handles. As for the over all shave the Mach 3 wins hands down. I always take a double shave. I did the first pass with the Feather and reached out for my Mach 3 for the second pass over to finish the job.<br />In summation the Mach 3 is expensive, but well worth the price. For you young bucks I say give the Feather a whirl you might like it and save some money in the process. I'm sticking to my Mach 3!
  181. This is my first foray into the world of double edge shaving. I wore a beard from the time started growing facial hair until I was 36 and by then started with multi-edged shaving devices and electric. I decided to take the plunge into the world of double edged shaving and the Feather Razor met the mark. It is light and well built. Though some parts are plastic I do not see that as a fault. It is very light and easy to maneuver. Make no mistake, you will draw blood on your first attempts, I sure did! But, as another reviewer stated you are either getting better at it or you are planing down the high spots. My wife says the shave is as close as Fusion gets me. It does take more time, or you will be sorry. The Fusion is much more forgiving but double edge shaving is more rewarding! As a beginner I can say that this would be a good starter and likely a keeper for the double edge shaver. UPDATE 4/20/14: I've been using the Feather Razor now for 5 months. My first shave was a bit of a nightmare! I was wearing a white Tee-shirt and after the first shave it was flecked with red from the nicks and scrapes of that first go at it. But I continued and have gotten better and I believe that you are really planing down the high spots on your face as well. I get a good shave blood free these days. The process has sped up, but is still slower than the Fusion. I enjoy it more than using the using the Fusion for some reason, maybe because of the perceived danger involved. One thing I did note is that I often do not shave every day and may go several days between shaves. I have a medium to heavy beard. The feather handles this type of shaving much better than any multi-edge shaver I have ever used. It doesn't get clogged up at all. As far as the durability of the Feather is has proven very durable showing no wear, tear or malfunction. I have only used Shark Super Chrome blades and they work great. Cleaning and oiling (I use baby oil) the blade after use gives an extra 1-2 shaves and they are noticeably smoother than not oiling. UPDATE 10/03/14: I have been using this razor now for about 9 or 10 months and have recently purchased it some company. I wanted to try out a screw together style and not wanting to spend much money on the trial I got a Baili for about $14. This gives me something to compare the Feather to.From this experience the Feather is a less aggressive design. It doesn't shave quite as close, but it feels safer. Using the Baili I have to be more careful due to the added aggression of the design. This makes the Feather a better choice for beginners and those with less aggressive beards. God knows what my first shave would have been like with the Baili! The Feather drew enough blood! As far as the speed of shaving I am almost up to par with shaving with the Fusion. I have switched to Wilkinson Sword blades and they are the best I have used yet! I'm getting 5 easy shaves from a blade with them. I could push it to 6 or 7 and still be doing better than after 3 with the Sharks. I am really enjoying double edge shaving. I highly recommend the Feather, it is a great product!
  182. A definite winner!! Love how this razor shaves, nice mild cut with excellent balance and feel. Shaves like a much higher priced razor. You would almost have to try to cut yourself with this razor, even with the extremely sharp blades included with it.
  183. Unbelievably cheap for what you get. It is very solid feeling. It is plastic but it has a great feel in the hand. The blade is held firmly in place. I liked the blades that came with it, maybe a little sharp for a beginner. Once your skin gets used to them they are great! I have ordered the same blades in a separate order.

  194. I like this double edge razor. I am able to get a closer shave than when I use a multi-blade razor.
  195. This is an excellent razor. The long handle helps prevent slippage. The twist handle blade release makes it easy to change the blade. In my experience, you can't buy this in stores. It is, or is similar, to perfected razors from the 60's or 70's. It is sad you can't purchase this now in any stores that I have checked. I guess they want to sell the much more expensive (per shave) disposable razors with 2 to 5 blades. I get as good a shave, or better, with this razor. Plus, I am only disposing of metal blades which are Earth friendly. The plastic disposable razors are not, and you have to dispose of the whole razor. Every time I disposed of one of those expensive plastic razors, I thought about the swirling mass of plastic in the Pacific Ocean covering an area the size of Texas! But, even if you are not into environmental issues, you can get as good a shave, or better, with this razor saving half the cost, or more, depending on what disposable razor (that I have found) you might want to compare it with. I gave it 4 stars only to leave room because I haven't tried them all. I am very happy with this razor.
  196. holds the blade perfectly and at the right angle to prevent cuts or skin irritation. shaves great, you can go against the grain for a smooth shave without worries.
  197. Very good razor for price. Not as heavy as other more expense razors but sufficient as inexpensive version. Bought one for each of my brothers. They like as well.
  198. I have been using the merkur 38c for the past 6 years with great results, I also have the merkur bakerlite which I also enjoy as does my wife. So when I got this razor it was going to be for my 15yr son as his introduction into the world of wet shaving, of course I had to try it first to make sure it wasn't going to butcher his face. I have very sensitive facial skin especially my neck area, I am sporting a chin strap beard and I have found shave secret oil to be the best protection for my face giving me a clean close cut free shave while allowing me to see my lines. Having said that, I had not shaved for 5 days when this razor arrived so I put in one of my gellette silver blue blades, oiled up with my shave secret shave oil and had at it. Many say this is a mild shaver and I found that to be true as well, but mild in this case does not equal not close and clean on the contrary. This razor gave a very close shave (bbs) with only three passes and no irritation on my neck. At first I thought the handle was to long, but it turns out to be just right allowing precise handling in getting my lines barbershop straight. Now I thought well I did test it on a five days growth so irritation would have been minimal using any of my razors, so I shaved with it again one day later and again no irritation and as my wife commented my face was bbs! This has now become my daily shaver, I have yet to try it with the included feather blades, will try them next month when its time to change blades.

  213. There are several good, objective, comprehensive reviews of this razor already posted, and you should read them. What I can add to them is how the razor works with a tough beard. For some reason most of the men who are double-edge shaving (or at least the ones who write about it) seem to have sensitive skin and medium or light beards. I have neither. If you have a coarse or heavy beard you will be making several passes with this razor because it is MILD. The typical three passes probably will not be enough so allow yourself some extra time for your morning shave.<br />If you are a beginning DE shaver that mildness is not necessarily a bad thing. This was the first razor I tried and even with the Feather blades, reputed to be the sharpest razors available, I was never able to cut or nick myself. That is something I can't say about the more expensive razors I purchased later. The &#34;Popular&#34; is light and mostly plastic but the fairly long handle gives it a nice balance. I found it to be a great razor to learn about DE shaving with. You may not hand this down to your grandchildren but you won't regret buying it.
  214. Just got this razor delivered, haven't shaved in 3 days, tried it out and I'm impressed. This is a really good cheap TTO safety razor. Great for the beginner. It is partially made of plastic so it doesn't have the weight that an all metal razor would have but I like the design. I will get a much heavier razor at some point, I have a birthday coming up soon but I'm glad I bought this one first just to learn with. I've never used a TTO razor until today and I was expecting it to be a rough bloody endeavor but surprisingly it wasn't that bad. I only knicked myself once and it barely even bled. I got the el-cheapo soap and have some razor burn but overall I'm very pleased with this purchase...when I get a heavier razor I'll just use this Feather as a travel razor and it comes in a clear plastic folding travel case.
  215. I would say that this razor is good for beginners like myself who are making that switch from cartridge razors to safety razors. Yes this is made of plastic, but the head is made of metal, and it's still heavier than multiblade razors, but lacks the heft that all metal safety razors have. I've had this for a month now, and it's given me good shaves, it's also easy to clean and maintain, and it's pretty affordable. So if you want to start using a safety razor, but aren't entirely comfortable shelling out $25+ for one, try this one, you won't be disappointed.

  221. I use this razor daily and just can't find a real fault. For a TTO razor the blades are held in place in the correct position every time I use it. The tightening nut always stays tight and it is very easy to clean. No rust issues, no stuff feeling cheap issues, it just works. I know there are many shaving snobs who insist on a Parker, Jagger, or Muehler razor and I agree that they look better and are fancier but I just want to shave. This razor has gotten some bad press due to the plastic handle. The only reason this isn't a 5 star review is that the handle does get slippery whereas the Edwin Jagger I also have doesn't. I use this razor everyday over the Jagger because is simply feels like a better shave and that is the point right?<br /><br />Don't let the price fool you - this is a good, serviceable razor and it even comes with a five pack of Feather blades. If you insist on spending $200 on a razor, I would highly suggest the Feather All Stainless - my barber uses that one when I get a shave there and it feels awesome. Just not worth $200 awesome for me.

Need to slightly turn the neck to let shaving &#34;debris&#34; out when rinsing in water. The butterfly doors need to be opened when you're done with a swipe so the hair can be let out. Otherwise it just &#34;clogs&#34; and sticks inside.<br /><br />3. Butterfly &#34;wings&#34; (whatever you want to call it) sometimes get stuck or don't open all the way.

  228. I finally got tired of the expense of the $4+ Fusion cartridges and ordered this Feather DE razor. I wanted to experience DE shaving without dropping a ton of $ on the shaver since, I thought, I might not like the single blade shave. My shaver arrived on time as scheduled, as is usual with Amazon:-) I like the hard plastic case the Feather was shipped in. It will serve as a travel case. The razor's handle is plastic, but it has a nice feel, is textured, and provides good grip when my hands are wet (I shave in the shower). The build of the razor is very good, it in no way feels flimsy, and it secures the blade very securely. All-in-all, the razor is well-built, and the butterfly mechanism works smoothly. Much of the Feather is made of plastic, but it doesn't feel &#34;plasticky&#34;. I wondered a bit about how that first shave would go since I had been shaving with disposable cartridges for almost forty years. I made sure to prep my face well, and I used King of Shaves Alphagel since I had used it most recently on my last couple of months of Fusion cartridge shaving. I found the Feather, with it's Feather blade (2 were shipped with the razor), to be easy to use, very effective at removing my heavy beard, and it gave me a great shave without even one nick or cut! I used that same blade for just over two weeks before it began to give me a tinge of irritation (after shaving I wipe the blade with an alcohol-soaked cotton ball to avoid having hard water minerals and shave gel corrode the steel). One month of Fusion cartridges would equal what I paid for this Feather razor and it's two included blades. I just now ordered 50 Feather blades (I'll say, very conservatively, A YEAR's supply of blades), for about what another 4 cartridges (A MONTH OR LESS of shaves) would have cost. The shaves I get with my Feather are as good or better as those with the Fusion. The head of the Feather is much easier to clean and much less likely to clog as were the Fusion's. I'm still regretting not making the switch years ago. The Feather Double Edge Shaving Razor (and it's Feather blades!) get my highest recommendation! Buy one - you, your face, AND your wallet will be happy you did! ********************************* UPDATE 07JUNE2015 - How do I feel about my Feather razor after 14 months? Still feeling the love. The Feather razor itself has performed almost every day for 14 months without any sign of breakage or loosening. My shaving technique is better. I have found an inexpensive, high-tallow shaving soap, Arko, that I really like. I'm quite satisfied with the Feather blades that I have used since converting to wet shaving w/a safety razor. And the damage is less than two bucks per month, even when switching blades every Sunday morning. I wish I had converted years ago. And I give the Feather Double Edge Shaver a very high &#34;Buy&#34; recommendation!

  231. Yes, there are some plastic parts but don't be fooled by that. This is a very capable razor, the blade aligns perfectly (not necessarily the case even in razors much more expensive). It's also very forgiving in the sense that you don't have to hold it in a &#34;perfect&#34; angle for it to do its job. The only minor complain might be that since the handle is plastic it's a little top heavy. The upside is that it's more agile and since I shave the &#34;cabeza&#34; too that suits me fine. Lastly, the blades that it comes with are super sharp, so much so that I prefer to use the Personna blades instead.

  246. this gives a pretty good shave, much better than the el-cheapo one I tried for les than $3 a few months ago. It will save a fortune compared to the disposable cartridges.
  247. I had never heard of safety razors before, however I became interested in them when I found the feather pack of 50 blades for $16 dollars here on amazon while searching for cheaper razors. After looking into it, these razors really do make the most sense cost wise. I can shave about 4 times with each razor (each has 2 edges, so 2 shaves per edge), which means the 50 blades I bought will last 200 days! Definitely the most cost effective approach to shaving I have found yet!<br /><br />The other upside I have found to these razors is that nearly every shave is with a brand new razor. If you think about bic razors and how sharp they are on the first cut, shaving with the razor is essentially getting that perfect edge shave every time you shave. I love it!<br /><br />The biggest downside of these razors is that the head doesn't &#34;swivel&#34; like cartridge razors do. As a guy, shaving my face really wasn't any more difficult, it just took a couple days to get used to a slightly different technique, though I have yet to cut myself with it! (This was a concern when I bought it as I heard that it is easier to cut yourself, but I have had no issues) However, my girlfriend wanted to try it for her legs and she found it very hard to use because the razor must be held at the right angle to cut, so it was difficult for her to hold it like that while getting hard to reach places.<br /><br />As far as the razor itself, I was a little concerned initially because it is made out of plastic in parts, but I have had no issues with it! The contraption that holds the blade in places works great, and the razor feels very sturdy despite being made of plastic.
  248. Bought this and a box of 100 Personna blades and my first shave was amazing. So it had been a few days since my last shave and my hairs were quite long. I thought this would be the perfect test because at this point if I would've used a multi-blade, it would've been torture with all the tugging, pulling and razor burn. I don't have sensitive skin but do get bumps if I don't use the right razor or shave with a multi when my hairs are longer than the width of a fingernail! The basic, single blade Feather sliced right thru like I had just a little shadow. Coming from disposables I can appreciate the lightweight feel of this razor. Not much else to say about this razor.

Basically you go really, really light and keep the thing almost perpendicular to the floor, just slightly angled down. This link had good advice, start about this halfway down: [...]
  250. I'm sure this is a good razor for those who know what they're doing but not for the rest of us. You're starting with a DE razor this is both difficult to use and unforgiving. What I discovered too late is that Feather is a Japanese brand and their blades are well known for being some of the sharpest on the market making them not recommending for beginners. I lost a pint of blood doing a simple head shave. Also, the adjustable collar is a nice feature but it doesn't stay where you set it for long. If I didn't keep it in the tightest setting, which sets the blade at the steepest angle, I would constantly have to readjust the setting every few passes. It did provide a close shave and DE razors are very economical but this is just garbage.

  256. This Razor is very attractive, well build and give a close none aggressive shave.It has become one of favorites, The Razor is a Classical.
  257. Smooth shave, holds blade evenly (Compared to another purchase) and has a nice sized comfortable handle (Again, compared to another purchase). Liked so much gave my first review and ordered another as a back up.
  258. I ordered this razor as a travel piece that I would not cry over if lost for any reason ... I've grown attached to my Weber razor and no longer risk it to the TSA folks, they can be moody in some parts of the world.<br />This razor is a fine tool!! I have been using DE razors for over 60 years and this fine instrument holds it's own against any as far as shaving quality. Obviously, for the price, it's not going to compare with my all stainless, polished Weber in appearance but that's not what we're discussing here.<br />The safety bar on this razor would allow a moron to wack away at their face without much threat. I have never so much as nicked myself with this gentle razor even when violating all the rules and shaving against the grain. I have a medium heavy beard and it's no push over!!<br />Regarding the mechanics of this tool here is what I recommend. After using it for over a year this works. I keep the main supporting pin and the tightening mechanism lubricated with a drop of 3 in one oil about once a month. I clean the razor a little every three or four days. I NEVER TIGHTEN THE PLATFORM CAP MORE THAN FINGER 'SNUG'!!!! That's all that is necessary to perfectly seat the blade that is precision placed by the guide bar.<br />I use cheap, $2.00 a can, Barbasol shaving cream because it easily clears with a splash of water from any DE razor. This is not true of some gels and some other shaving potions. I loosen the mechanism after shaving and do not apply any pressure again until the next shave ... this preserves the mechanism. This razor's moving parts are all stainless and, yes, they are not hefty but that makes no difference. Treated with some care, don't screw down on the lifting mechanism, this razor could last someone for years and years!!!!<br />No, it is not my Weber Stainless but it is one fine, forgiving, well constructed, for it's purpose, razor!!! You will never go wrong for the price here and you won't go wrong with it mechanically unless you unnecessarily stress the head my jacking down on the lifter!!!
  259. I had tried Feather blades before I bought this razor; at that time I used the blades in fixed angle razors and in adjustable ones, in each case finding that the blades were very sharp and in each case nicking myself. With this razor, the cutting angle is such that I get a close shave and rarely cut myself. Although I like/prefer Feather blades, I've found that my Merkur blades also work well in this razor. Once I've used up my old supply of Merkurs, I'll probably stick with the Feather blades.

  263. I must say that I was very pleasantly surprised by this DE razor. I have a small collection of DE Razors, including an Edwin Jagger DE89BL and a Parker 22R, and this plastic handled Feather razor definitely holds its own against them. My personal favorite is the Edwin Jagger, but to keep that chrome bright and shiny is a little extra work that I don't want to have to worry about each morning -- so I use it only on the weekends or when I know I have a little extra time.<br /><br />The Feather razor is pretty light, but gives a nice, close, and comfortable three pass shave. With a quick pat dry and easy blade removal via the butterfly mechanism, I am on my way. I can't recommend this razor enough as an excellent, economical every day DE razor. I should qualify that I don't mean that it is good \\"for the price.\\" It is great little razor that puts some of my other more expensive razors to shame!
  264. I am giving this product four stars, but not because the razor itself is inferior. I actually love the look, the light weight, the one-piece design, and the \\"butterfly\\" method of placing the blade. Its very easy to operate.<br /><br />The thing is... we all have different beards and different face contours, so this razor is not going to be consistent for everyone. In my case, I just could not get a close shave. I really gave this razor an opportunity to shine. I tried different creams and a variety of blades, but had to give up. It's simply not aggressive enough for me. I am not going to disparage this product. But the only way to see if this razor is for you is to try it and hope for a sound return policy.

  275. I thought it would be hard to adjust back to using a Safety Razor, but it was like riding a bicycle. A little strange at first, but easy to remember the process. I've very happy with my Feather. It came with 2 razor blades included and they both gave me a very nice and close shave. No knicks as of yet. At first, I thought the razor looked a little cheap because of all of the plastic, but it does a great job holding the razor tightly and it also cleans up nicely with just running water. I also found that if i twist the top open just a little when I clean it, all of the gunk collected on the blades slides off with just running water. What I really like is not having to pay $4 a blade for Fusion or Gillette. I switched about a year ago to Harry's but those blades turn out to be about $2 each. With the Feather and Personna blades, I am only paying about 31 cents per blade. Big difference and a much closer shave. I do recommend this razor.

  280. I’ve been using this razor for a month now and I’m completely satisfied. The long handle and light weigh closely approximates my cartridge razor so it feels comfortable and familiar in my hand. I was a bit surprised as this razor produced less nicks and burning sensation after my shave. The blade fits evenly in the head and both edges are exposed exactly the same. I tried a more expensive razor and the shorter handle and additional weight were in my opinion a real disadvantage especially with wet or soapy hands. All I really want is a razor that produces a close and comfortable shave and the Feather does that without question.
  281. I found myself tired of paying nearly $4 a cartridge for Gillette razor blades. After doing some research, I decided to try a double edge razor. Since I have a very sensitive face, I did not want to spend $30+ on a razor that I may only use once. The Feather razor was a reasonable option. It comes pre-packaged with two razor blades. The top of the blade where the shaving area is located is made out of metal. The handle is plastic, however the overall unit still have a good quality feel to it. The top of the razor unscrews easily to change out blades. If you are still unsure about D/E shaving, this would be a good option to try it out.<br /><br />On a side note: I feel like I get a closer shave with D/E razors, however new blades do seem to irritate my skin more than Gillette cartridges. After a couple of shaves, the blades get more dull and this irritation subsides. The major benefit of D/E razors is the low cost of use. A 100 pack of razors only costs $10.

  283. Fifty three years ago, started with a safety razor Gillette. While in college and for four years in the army and a few years afterward until the Trac-2 arrived that was all I used. Got great shaves and the occasional nick but nothing serious. I used Wilkinson Sword Blades and really liked them. They even worked well with cold water shaves in the field in Vietnam. Then the blades and razors disappeared. The Trac-2 and its ilk were OK but they never really gave a close shave. I really didn't like the 3, 4, or 5 blade razors. They were and are obscenely expensive. So about 6 years ago I switched to electric. At first they gave good shaves, but in the last 6 months, even after replacing shaving heads, I just didn't get a close shave. So, I switched back to the best of the multiblades that worked for me the two-blade razors from Shick/Wilkinson. I wasn't too happy, Then I &#34;rediscovered&#34; that you can by DI blades and razors.<br />I received my Feather Popular two days ago. It works well. Yes, it's plastic, but it appears to be a high grade industrial plastic. The fit and finish is excellent. The first few shaves with the supplied Feather Blades were smooth and close, Yes, I could do better, but I have to get back in shape, so to speak. I will be trying out some different blades I expect to receive in a few days, and will try them out and update this evaluation. I will say the razor does hold the blades securely and shaving is a pleasure.<br />I am only giving 4 stars a this time, but I may change that after using the razor for a while.   284. I'm a new wet shaver, so I don't have anything to compare against other than cartridge razors. Based on what I've read and the few weeks I've been using this on both head and face, this seems to be a very mild razor. I bought it with a sample pack of blades and have started with the ones that I've read are a little milder and am slowly working my way up to the Feather blades, which I've heard are very sharp. So far I've only had a few nicks that were easily cleaned up with a styptic pencil. I'm pretty sure most of the nicks were due to poor beginner technique.<br /><br />Depending on the blade I use, I get a pretty good WTG / XTG shave with about 4 passes. I have very thick hair, and as I mentioned, am currently using milder blades. Keeping with WTX / XTG shaves, keeping well lathered, and using good prep, I have almost no irritation. Shaving ATG is really necessary for me to get a BBS shave. I have found it very difficult to shave ATG with this razor and the milder blades without irritation.<br /><br />Compared to my old cartridge razors, I do get a much better shave with less irritation, but it takes me an hour to shave both head and face, compared to 15 minutes with my old cartridge razors in the shower. I've only been using this razor for 3 weeks, so time will tell how well the plastic holds up. It does seem to be a little on the light side for a DE shaver, so it takes a lot of effort to not apply pressure.

  292. You get everything you expect from this razor. It does what you expect. The only problem I have with it is it's light weight. If you are thinking about trying a wet shave for the first time I would encourage you to pick this up and give it a try. There is nothing quite like it. I had been using cartridge type systems for over 25 years and finally decided to give safety razors a try. I am experiencing the closest shaves I have had in my entire life and the least amount of irritation too. I do not understand why this is, but I am pleasantly surprised. Yes, you need to take your time and resist the urge to press the razor down into your face, but once you get the hang of it you will be happy.<br /><br />For the record, I have an extremely heavy beard, and this is the only way I have been able to get a good shave.   309. This is my second DE razor. I had a Parker model before. This one may be plastic, but it feels very solid. It's survived MANY falls in the shower and a few trips in a bag. So, don't be turned off because It's plastic. Besides, I think some of the parts are metal.<br /><br />It's MUCH more gentle than the Parker razor I had before. I don't think it shaves quite as close, but it is still quite a close shave. That's probably why the Parker wasn't as gentle.<br /><br />I really liked the included Feather blades. Some people claim they're too sharp, but this isn't an aggressive razor so I think they work well together. I bought a sampler pack of blades and was surprised to find my next favorite blade is the Bic Chrome Platinum.<br /><br />Overall, this was a great razor for a great price.
