  310. I wouldn't say this is a terribly aggressive DE Razor. The side view of the top let's you see the angle of the dome that comes down on the blade. It's not terribly aggressive but I wouldn't say its the best choice for sensitive skin.<br /><br />That being said the blade is only as good as your level of skill and level of prep. Even an unskilled shaver can get a masterful shave with the proper amount of quality prep for their skin type. This handle comes with Feather Razors. They're exceedingly sharp and good for 3, maybe 4 shaves depending on the level of prep and how close you want to get.<br /><br />With that being said I only wish the handle were a bit longer.The handle itself is rather light and easy to manipulate, but the lightness of the handle makes it hard to properly gauge the angle the head is at as well as grip it properly. Something with a bit more weight would force you to concentrate on how you're gripping it instead of how hard you're gripping it. This is also a function of the plastic grooves on the handle.<br /><br />Something with more weight would be easier to handle with less pressure. Applying less pressure or force to the handle will allow the razor to do its job. Without getting a super-expensive metal DE Razor (well worth it regardless) a happy compromise would be lengthening the handle on a DE like this.<br /><br />After the prep and the shave you still have to clean this razor. I considered dropping it another point just for the head assembly. It collects hair and makes it hard to keep the chamber where the razor is kept clean and dry. It's only a few extra seconds work and I'm not expecting a hermetic seal but the grooves and channels in the plastic parts of the head are difficult to get a towel in and even with a hanging razor rack you'd have to find a place to keep the razor blade while the handle hung upside down and completely open to air dry.<br /><br />This I would say is a good starter razor and an excellent one for someone willing to settle.to settle.
  311. This was my first DE razor and it was perfect. It's not too aggressive and is pretty good quality for the price. I used this for about a year and only used it for shaving my head. I recommend it if you're switching from a multi-blade razor to a DE. I moved on to a more aggressive razor but this was a great razor for my beginning stage of DE razor use.
  312. I bought this as my first double edge safety razor, and it's definitely a good budget razor. I'm not sure if it's the feather blades or the razor itself, but it does tend to cause irritation after a couple months of use. I think it's because the razor itself started to degrade in quality because of the cheaper materials used. I found myself having to replace the blade more and more often to get a comfortable shave. I'd still recommend purchasing this if you're wanting to try DE shaving, but consider a less aggressive blade (feathers are the sharpest ones available, and dig into your skin whenever they hit a thick hair patch)
  313. works like it supposed to.
  314. I use Feather blades so I figured this was a good idea. Its a pain to disassemble my Merkur MK030 to change blades so I was intrigued by the twist-to-open design of the Feather. Somehow the angle of the blade on this razor is totally wrong. Shaving with this thing is like dragging a butter knife across your face. When it does manage to remove any hair, it does so unevenly. Avoid Avoid Avoid! The twist-to-open concept is solid and deserves to be perfected. This product needs to be redesigned.
  315. My husband loves the razor. Says it is much cheaper to use than the fancy disposable ones being sold
  316. This razor is wonderful! I've been wetshaving for over 5 years now, and I've currently got a Merkur 34c and a Merkur Futur in my rotation, at $35 and $75 respectively. This little $15 plastic Japanese razor blows the expensive Germans out of the water. My beard is exceptionally heavy, and my skin is somewhat sensitive, but I decided that for the price, I wouldn't regret the purchase if this thing didn't work out. After shaving with it, It's my new primary. It's not very aggressive, and coupled with the samurai-sharp feather blades, this butterfly-top is simply brilliant. I've never been able to shave against the grain in my life, but that all changed with this thing. the last time my face was this smooth, I was eleven years old!<br />The key is using a feather-light touch (pun somewhat intended), and somewhat shorter strokes than one would with a Merkur or EJ. I've found the angle to be somewhat different as well, but with the longer handle, it's fairly natural.<br />As a collector of traditional shaving tools, I may find myself ponying up for the feather all-stainless razor in the future, but I don't imagine that the shave could be terribly much better; this thing is that good.<br />If you're concerned about the materials that it's made of, consider this: The Nipponese have been making little plastic cars for quite some time, and as anyone will tell you, they're far more reliable than their expensive Prussian counterparts... The build quality of this razor is fantastic, and although it may not have that Mercedes-benz status attached to it, It's simply a joy to use and I don't feel like it's going to fall apart anytime soon. Buy it!
  317. Best shaving razor I ever had. you can adjust the dept of the shaving which is nice feature. I love it.
  318. have not used de since 1971 but thus is a great razor not very aggressive easy to learn with works great with feather blades better with blue personnas
  319. I’m an African American male who was in the market for a shaving alternative to combat razor bumps and general skin irritation that oftentimes plague men of color …..Like most guys I used both Gillette and Schick razors for years, spending hundreds of dollars yearly on wherever new motorized shaving device they came up with. Despite paying exorbitant fees for ‘motor razors’, I oftentimes found shaving to be a dreaded chore, something to rush through…..only to be left with razor bumps that despite my best efforts, continued to appear.<br />The cost for replacement cartridges from Gillette and Schick is OUTRAGEOUS! I mean really $15 or more for a set of FIVE??!! If the cost doesn’t dissuade you, the quality of the shave should…..From what I understand, these razors ‘pull/rip’ the hair follicle from your skin [increasing the potential for skin irritation and razor bumps]<br />After doing some research I learned about the ART of shaving using a traditional safety razor YouTube is your friend, use it!] . Sure, I like most newbies was concerns about slicing my face to shreds with a blade but believe it or not the process ain’t bad at all…in fact the learning curve was NOT daunting for me.<br />The Feather Safety razor is easy to use [‘the screw open’ loading mechanism] is simple to use. The starter blades I chose were the Astra brand [a pack of 100 blades for $10]<br />I also purchased a shaving cup and brush set, again entry level [about $9 for a set]….<br />Overall, I must say that my shaves have been GREAT! Once you go down the route of making shaving an experience and not a chore, there is no going back!<br />This shaving experience requires that you tailor a process for your particular lifestyle and skin type, for example if you have course hair like me, you might need a bit more prep time [i.e. heat and lubrication on the beard 1st] In my case, the morning shaving routine consists of the following:<br />1. Wash face with moisturizer face wash<br />2. Fill sinkwith HOT water and soak blade<br />3. While blade is soaking, make lather in soap cup<br />4. Coat face and proceed with shave [shave beard with 2 complete passes]<br />5. Rinse face and add lubrication moisturizer [I use Shea moisture –tea tree Herbal Bump preventer]<br />Free yourself from the Gillette/Schick rip off …..You’ll be glad you did!
  320. This razor is unbelievably good--and would be at any price. It out-performs razors costing two or three times as much. (By that I mean DE safety razors, not the multi-blade monstrosities most of us have scraped our faces with over the years. DE safety razors inhabit a superior universe.) This modest little marvel sets the super-sharp Feather blade at an unusual but perfect angle and shaves like an effortless dream. The best shave I've ever had. I recently reviewed an open-comb razor and raved about its performance. This razor is superior. I can't imagine any of the top-of-the-line Feather models doing a better job.

  328. Bought this to try out the double edge experience. Yes, Im a newbee, been using cartridge razors for 20+ years.<br />This razor is lightweight but still needs very little pressure (if any... depends on how thick your beard grows). Lightweight and parts are plastic but it is made very well. Took 2 times using this to get a nice, close shave with it, bascially because I needed to get used<br />to getting the right angle. The blades that come with it are super sharp but you can come away nick-free using the right angle and<br />a little patience. This is not a razor to drag across your face for a quick 60 second shave, like you can a cartridge blade. Now that I am used to it, I can breeze through a shave relatively quickly and haven't had any problems cutting/nicking my face. This will get you a much closer shave than a cartridge razor with less passes across your face. All in all, very nice...would recommend! Hope this helps.
  329. Decided to move back to shaving with a safety razor and have since moved back to a straight razor. Heard a lot about Feather quality but did not want to spend a couple hundred dollars to check it out. This one was reasonably priced and I knew from the start that weight and balance was not going to happen with a safety razor made of plastic. The build was very good for a cheap razor. The shave is amazingly close and I find that I can be more aggressive in my shaving technique with this safety razor than with my straight. The included Feather blades are excellent blades and I would recommend using those blades for any safety razor. I use this as my back-up razor whenever I am in a rush and it has never let me down. I would highly recommend this razor.
  330. It would be very hard to cut or nick your face with this razor it is very forgiving even when you use bad technique. The reason for 3 stars because its does not give a close enough Shave for me. I like that baby smooth feel when I have finished shaving and this razor did not deliver that for me or her.

  332. What can be said about this razor that hasn't already been said. I've been using it for about a month with feather razor blades. The razor does what its suppose to do...namely assist in giving me a clean and close shave. Feels good in my hand. Good weight and good length. My hands are probably of average size. Not huge but not small. The razors that I use fit snuggly inside the butterfly and do not jiggle around while I'm shaving. It is a combination of metal and plastic. The handle is plastic and very light. The butterfly is metal. In terms of functionality the plastic parts don't affect your shave. In terms of appearance...ya an all metal razor would look cooler, but I'm really more interested in how well this thing does its intended job. In terms of price...well you can't beat it. So the value is definitely there. It does everything that I've expected it to do and it is inexpensive so it gets 5 stars in my book.
  333. I have been using this razor for a couple weeks now and I shave every 2-3 days with it. I wanted to try it because I get ingrown hairs on my neck when I shave and peoples' comments seem to suggest that this is a good razor to try.<br /><br />Some thoughts:<br /><br />The 'learning curve' is a little bogus, it didn't take much time at all to figure this guy out. Sure, watching a video on Youtube is useful to help you respect the DE razor, but it isn't rocket surgery.<br /><br />My ingrown hairs did not go away completely, at first. It seems like each successive shave has reduced the irritation, it may be because the razor doesn't shave your hair clean to the bone like a 7-bladed razor does; it is likely that I am now paying closer attention to the direction my hairs grow and try to only shave with the grain, not across or against. I'm sure that both factors help. The bottom of my neck has been the worst and I used to shave it last. Last week I started shaving it first to give it the attention that it needs and I think that is very helpful.<br /><br />The Feather DE razor is a very high quality blade! The other day I pulled out a brand new Gillette 2-blade and a Schick 5-blade just to compare the experience, and honestly, there is nothing to compare. The Feather blade is much sharper and manufactured to a higher quality than the disposables or the cartridges.<br /><br />Overall, I am very happy with this, I'd say my neck irritation is about 10% what it used to be and to me, that makes all the difference.

The blade also got stuck on long hairs, they did not cut smooth, this is great for somebody with leather like skin with thick stubble whom already shaves with a Mach3 or single blade disposable type razor. It is defiantly not better than electric.

  341. I wanted to have the ability to store a razor and numerous blades in case a shortage develops. The razor was to come with two, free blades. The vendor informed me by e-mail that the supplier had shipped him units w/o the blades which, unknowingly, he had transshipped to me. Consequently, my order was to be free. The razor arrived with the blades. The only way I can repay the vendor's honesty is to give him a good review. Unfortunately, I lost the label with his name on it. Sorry. He is in Thailand, the only one I saw from there. Thank you, whomever you are. I value your honorable treatment.<br /> The razor seems well-made; the blades seem to be sharper than those to which I am accustomed. I cut myself seven times during the first shave with the Feather...my fault, not the razor's. The touch technique needed for a safety razor is very different from that needed for using a Gillette Mach 3. I immediately ret. to the Mach 3. I have neither time nor patience (right now) for learning safe use of this instrument. I bought shaving gel from Walmart, but have not had a chance to use it with the Feather.

I can avoid too much irritation by accepting an OK shave, or I can go for the baby butt smooth shave and end up doctoring some pretty good nicks.   379. I have a Feather Safety Razor and use Prorasor Shaving soap or sometimes Old Tayolors Almond shaving soap and hot water. I love there razors. These to me are equal to quality as Feathers or maybe even alittle better. These give great shave and last a week shaving everyday. I also tried Shark Chrome razors which are good but not as good as Feather or Astra. WIth any safety razor use a good quality shaving soap like Taylors or Prorasor and use hot water to rise face before lather and during shave to rinse blade. Very easy to use. Dont let the reviews about how different it is to shave with these types of razors. Shave exactly the same way as your normal razor except use lighter pressure as these are more sharp. Takes only five seconds to put on a new blade and is very easy to do. Tip, spend the money and buy a shaving brush like a badger brush to bush on a good quality shaving soap.(to save time just run brush under hot water and dip ends of brush into the shaving soap and spin the brush around for a few seconds then apply to face. I don't have time before work to mix up a bowel or mug or shaving soap. This simple method works great at least for me.).

  385. This was my first DE Safety Razor, and I've owned it for almost a year.<br /><br />I've been mostly happy with it. For the price, this was an excellent investment that significantly improved my shaving regime. The plastic handle has not been an issue. It is sturdy, and somehow stays quite clean.<br /><br />However, the plastic 'base' of the razor head is extremely prone to soap scum and gunk. It's mainly a cosmetic issue, but I've had a lot of problems keeping it clean.<br /><br />Different brands of razor blades fit and perform differently in this razor. I now find myself looking for an adjustable razor as a replacement, to get better control on the aggressiveness of the razor. Not a problem with this razor, per se, but you may outgrow what this razor provides.
  386. I ordered both a Feather Double Edge and the Lord Premium L6. I have been using both now for a couple weeks. The Lord although cheaper is a much smoother and safer shave than this Feather. The Feather is much too aggressive, it nicks no matter how careful, and my face burns after a shave. The Lord L6 does not give this trouble. I tried using the Feather blade that this razor comes with and a couple other blades, still the Feather is too aggressive. Too bad because I really like the design and build of this razor and want to like it. This will not be my goto razor. I think there is a different razor for everyone, there are lots to choose from... we all have different face structures, beard thickness, and skin sensitivities.. So, on that this razor may be good for some, just not me.

I switched to a german all metal one but it does not side as well as this one. I will keep the both and use this one as my traveler!
  395. This was my first try at a safety razor. It works really well, and there is no &#34;learning curve&#34; really. It works almost the same way you use a standard disposable. The shave is a little less close, so it's a bit more akin to a &#34;sensitive skin&#34; shave, which suites me just fine. I had to check several stores before I found double-edge blades locally, but they are cheap to replace, so this is less expensive than even cheap disposables and it's a better shave. I like it.<br /><br />This razor is not adjustable. I've read comments from others saying that their safety razor is adjustable. But this one works great where its fixed. Any closer and it would probably cut you.<br /><br />This also works well on longer hair. So, if you've let certain areas go to long, this takes care of that hair quickly.
  396. This is an excellent razor and using it with a Feather blade is an excellent combination. This razor seems to be built very well and I like the twist open top.
  397. It was the closest shave iv ever had and and for the first time ever I did not cut myself. However, this razor has become my daily driver. This feather razor had no such learning curve. I can whip this thing around just like a cartridge razor! It may not look as cool as an all metal DE, but man it gets the job done perfectly!

  418. The two-sided razor design looks old-fashioned, but ideally suited for shaving. Most modern razors are overkill, with their over-priced multiple blades which are bad for the skin. For around two dollars you can buy a pack of around ten straight razors which are often better sharpened then most disposables. In addition, if your anything like me and put off shaving for any great length of time, the razor's housing can be opened to wash out the hair and prevent clogging. Try that with a regular razor.<br /> Although there is a lot of plastic in its construction, it doesn't feel cheaply made. The long handle gives excellent control, and the contact with the skin is, pardon the pun, “Feather” light. It is probably true you may not get as close a shave as some might prefer, but I personally like a very close shave. Use this with a few drops of Shave Secret and you'll have the best shave of your life. Comes in a plastic carrying case and with two free razors.
  419. Comparing this to my very expensive Merkur Vision 2000, I'll take the plastic Feather any day of the week. While I'd like to be able to afford the all-stainless Feather, the plastic one works perfectly, and I can't imagine any razor doing any better. I've used mine with both Feather blades and the generic drugstore blades, and performance is absolutely top-notch. I use Proraso pre/post shave cream and shaving cream. with an Omega bristle brush or a Dovo/Merkur silvertip badger brush. I'm buying a second to put in my travel kit, and will probably never use the Vision again. I could have bought five of the Feather for what I paid for the Merkur Vision, and given the other three as gifts. I don't miss the adjustability of the Vision at all; the Feather is perfect for me, and much easier to handle because of its lighter weight.

  427. I paid $20 for my Feather Popular razor and it is a very good quality razor.<br />Don't be mislead by the reviews that say it's a good &#34;Starter&#34; razor.<br />Yes there are more expensive razors out there, but cost doesn't always mean quality.<br /><br />The Feather is a good long term razor, well made and with quality precision construction.<br />Yes parts of it are plastic, but not the cheap plastic that comes to mind when someone says the word.<br /><br />The only thing that might be an issue is that Double Edge Razors and blades are an extremely personal thing.<br />A Razor and blade that gives one person a comfortable and a good shave, can be torture for someone else.<br /><br />When I first got this Feather razor it came with Feather DE Blades, and the shave was awful, left my face red and irritated.<br />Changed the blade to an Astra and it was a perfectly smooth and comfortable shave.<br /><br />So don't be discouraged if any Razor you buy (for any price) doesn't give you the shave you expected, experiment with different blades.<br /><br />Don't be put off by the price of the Feather Razor, it's a quality razor and can give you a great shave.<br />For me it will be a long term razor.<br /><br />March 2016. I bought this to try DE shaving, planning to replace it with something better. But I've now used this Feather razor for 2 years. Still gives a great shave. No need to buy anything else.

It's impossible to acutely nick yourself with this razor. So this produces a tendency to push down harder when shaving since it feels so benign... but this will give you fine cuts and razor burn.<br /><br />-Don't worry that some parts of it is made of plastic.   447. This was my first safety razor after using electric and disposable blades. The first time I used this, I was amazed.<br /><br />The razor is light, but appears to be well made. I was almost shocked at just how sharp they were. The drawback here seems to be blade life. I got 4 very comfortable, nick-free shave. The 5th was not so good, but I thought it might have been user error. Tried again, and it was even worse. The clever use of plastics allows the razor to 'glide' more readily than most (except for the occasional gold plated razors of the past). I think it's best to be a little careful with a double edge razor, but that's always been the case. I've tried the others, but comeback to the older approach.   461. Okay so I have waited to write a review.. sometimes a product impresses me but i don't take the time to actually write a review.. but this one is worthy of the effort. I am latino.. and i have curly.. so i an prone to getting ingrown hairs.. for YEARS i have conformed to simply accepting the fact that i will always have a mediocre or crappy shave... but i finally decided to research.. and i discovered DE razors.. and i can tell you i have never had a smoother shave and smoother face.. for black men, or anyone who has curly hair and are prone to ingrowns.. this is a must. I have also adopted the use of an alum bar.. it is amazing.. all these products i've never heard of.. are so much cheaper.. and have an amazing result. THe alum bar has eliminated the use of after shave entirely.. i am saving money.. having a better shave.. and using less products. The price of this DE is so cheap.. the quality could be better.. but for the price and the result who can complain? Also, i use this menthol eucalyptus shaving cream.. it is essential to lather very well.. it allows you to go against the grain and get a better shave. The alum bar.. which i never heard of before.. is so amazing.. it's so cheap.. and it will last you so long.. it is the best way to top off your shave.

  464. After years of using multi blade disposables in the shower the urge for something better came over me. My wife had three straight razors left by her grandad and I began to investigate. What I found was lots of info on straight razors and old double edge Gillette razors that were selling for an arm and a leg and articles and blogs by people who seemed to approach shaving as a ceremony more than a necessity with prices that to me could only be justified as the price to pay for spiritual enlightenment. No thanks. My practical side decided to look at Amazon and I settled on the Feather Double-Edge Razor because I did not want to disassemble and reassemble 3 pieces each time I changed the blade and the price was not excessive. Call me lazy, frugal or both. Also, my Gillette from many years ago was the same style. The combination plastic/metal construction concerned me at first but is no concern now after a month of daily use. The razor is quite easy to adjust to and the plastic handle may even be better as it does not slip when wet. My daily shave has been removed from the shower to the sink and is better than I have experienced in years. Another reviewer expressed concerns that the blade did not seat evenly in the razor and exposure was unequal. I have not noticed that with any of my blades in this razor.<br />I gave this item 4 stars instead of 5 because of the blades that came with it, not the razor. The razor is great. The blades also are excellent, just not suited to my skin. I found that the Feather Hi-Stainless Blades left my face smooth but burning. I used the two that came with the razor but have changed to the Wilkinson Sword Classics from Amazon. There is no burning post shave until the blade is about a week old. After shave stings a bit toward the end of the week, but nothing excessive. Sunday is blade change day and if I decide to change twice a week, blades are dirt cheap compared to the multi blades and the shave closer and more comfortable.<br />I would recommend this razor to anyone with a average beard as it does not seem to be overly aggressive. Those with very heavy beards may want something else but I'm certainly not the one to speak on that.<br />Given the choice I will never shave with a multi blade razor again. I also purchased brush and soap so perhaps I am headed for that ceremonial level. Nah, but it does feel good.<br />EDIT: February 2013. After two months using this razor in combination with the Wilkinson Sword blades I can honestly say that the process of shaving has gotten even easier. I cannot remember when in the past I would look forward to shaving. That is the case now. The Feather DE razor is holding up well, easy to clean after each shave and the blades last at least 10 shaves and remain comfortable. I run my hand across my face at some point in the day and smile at the comfort and smoothness. I changed the star rating to 5 stars based on the razor/blade combination I am now using, the Feather razor with Wilkinson Sword Stainless blades.
  465. Wasn't expecting this thing to be almost totally made of plastic, but leave it to those clever Japanese folks to design something that's so damn nice out of a relatively common material that works like a million bucks. Worth every cent, and then double it.
  466. Perfect for beginners to getting out of mainstream shaving. The amount of money and discomfort saved when jumping over to double edged shaving is astounding.
  467. U think is cheap but is not is a high quality material it gave me a good shave
  468. I just had my first shave with a double edge using this razor. As a rookie I chose this razor, which is reported to be very gentle, and paired with a Derby blade, also reported to be gentle. I have a fairly heavy beard, and many issues with irritation and bumps. I did a lot of research on technique, etc. Anyway, using this combo, some shaving oil, and starting out with a very clean face, I enjoyed the best shave ever. I went very slow, and was very careful. And my skin is much smoother than any shave before with no irritation. No cuts. I am frankly astonished by this. Very happy with this razor. Highly recommended
  469. Very nice razor. Well made considering it's made of plastic and metal. Put a Feather blade in it and it will shave close or closer than many more expensive razors. Very well designed razor. Good quality.
  470. I'm still getting used to the DE blade, minor nicks here and there, but I like it.
  471. Easy to use, good weight, easy to clean. I would recommend this razor
  472. Im 66 i havent shaved with this type in a lot of years. Worried how it will hold up because of plastic parts but it seems just great so far, opens to put in blades easily. Ill let u know if it dont hold up.
  473. Just got my first Feather Double Edge Razor today, and it 's a good razor. Will this be my last Feather Razor? No. Damn good product for the price. will be buying another one real soon.
  474. I bought this because I didn't want to buy a more expensive razor that I might or might not like. I'm coming from Gillette, Schick, and Dorco razors. I switched to DE razor to save money on blades. The feather blade is too sharp for me and I keep getting small cuts on my neck area. But the razor seems sturdy and I can't wait to try different blades on it.<br /><br />As many others have pointed out, this is a non-aggressive razor, meaning it's fairly hard to cut yourself with this razor. But the blade is still damn too sharp for a beginner. I would suggest to others that if this is going to be your first DE razor, I would buy other blades at the same time so that you are not stuck using Feather blades to begin with.<br /><br />Otherwise, I'm happy with DE shaving. I just wanted to save money, but it turns out to be quite more fun than regular cartridge shaving anyways. It's taking me longer than usual to shave now but that's because I have to be extra careful with Feather blade. As I get used to DE shaving, I don't think time consumption will be much of an issue.
  475. It's been 30+ yrs since I used a Double Edge Razor, & I did cut myself a couple of times...but after I got the touch back, this is the way to go. Yes, the Razor has a plastic handle but for $ 17 bucks, did you expect black Rhino horn?!<br /><br />I've had no problem with the head or the butterfly closure coming loose during shaving as some have posted, just seat the blade properly & snug the butterfly up. I do remove the blade, carefully wipe it dry as well as the razors head. Just like surgical equipment. Easy clean up!<br /><br />This is a great buy! Adios to those expensive razors & their out of their mind refill blades!
  476. Razor works great, its finding good blades I have a problem with..Seems like all I find are dull blades that pull..instead of cutting.
  477. i got into wet shaving about 9 months ago, as i was tired of spending a load of cash on disposable cartridges. after doing a decent amount of research on amazon, i chose this feather razor, a bulk package of feather hi-stainless blades, after shave lotion, shaving soap, and pre-shave cream from proraso, a brush from tweezerman and a steel brush stand. total investment: about $75. here we are, nearly 9 months later, and i have not spent a dime on any other shaving accessories, creams, etc. i was spending $18 a month on cartridges before. needless to say, i'm pleased with the cost savings.<br /><br />i am also very pleased with the shave quality. after a couple bloody shaving sessions, i started to get the hang of it, and have since developed a very enjoyable and fruitful shaving habit. the inclusion of the feather razor in that habit is a big part of that.<br /><br />being new to wet shaving, i spent some time playing around with the razor. i would twist the butterfly mechanism closed so far that the blade would be completely bent in against the head, which did not provide a very close shave. i would twist it open to the point that the blade lay flat and loose inside the head, and the shave would tear up my rough face. eventually i settled on a position where the blade would be slightly bent, and i get a great shave each time.<br /><br />the razor has held up so far just fine. all the parts still function correctly, and i have not had any issues with corrosion or deterioration. all the plastic bits are still fully intact as well. i have noticed that the razor likes to collect soap scum, but with a bit of scrubbing on it once a week or so, it remains pretty clean and doesn't suffer from build-up. since this is my first razor, i cannot offer comparisons to others. however, this razor could stand to be a bit heavier. i can see how a heavier razor would offer better balance and smoother operation.<br /><br />my only real gripe with this razor is in the butterfly mechanism. it is very easy to adjust, to the point where it adjusts too easily. i find myself having to close it back down just a bit every few minutes, because it tends to work its way loose over time.<br /><br />that being said, i still definitely recommend this razor for the budget-conscious consumer. i may upgrade to something a bit heavier and more expensive after a year with this one, but i see no reason that one cannot get by with only this razor from feather. i will keep using this one as my only razor, and will probably keep it as a backup / travel razor if i do decide to upgrade next year.m. it is very easy to adjust, to the point where it adjusts too easily. i find myself having to close it back down just a bit every few minutes, because it tends to work its way loose over time.<br /><br />that being said, i still definitely recommend this razor for the budget-conscious consumer. i may upgrade to something a bit heavier and more expensive after a year with this one, but i see no reason that one cannot get by with only this razor from feather. i will keep using this one as my only razor, and will probably keep it as a backup / travel razor if i do decide to upgrade next year.
  478. The Feather DE razor is made of some hard Bakelite kind of plastic and some metal. I can't attest to how long it will last - although it doesn't feel cheaply made at all - but I can say that it works brilliantly and simply. The butterfly open makes blade cleaning/changing a breeze. There's something about the cutting angle of the blade produced by this razor against the skin that makes this razor rock. I have used it with Feather, Wilkinson, and Personna DE blades and it works excellently with any of these blades. Although the razor feels lightweight, it is not necessary to use much pressure against your skin; a good, sharp blade and a good lather will do the job admirably.

  482. Just a couple days ago I came up with the idea I need something better than these modern gillette razors to shave with, so I did a little research, and man am I glad I went with a de razor (ESPECIALLY SINCE IT WAS THIS ONE RIGHT HERE). I'm a young gun, 21, and so this is a brand new experience for me to be shaving with de razors. I've read a bunch of reviews and watched youtube videos about the possible nicks and cuts you can cause yourself with a de so I was kind of worried about butchering my face up. Got this bad boy in the mail today, hopped in the shower, lathered my face up, and went to work. It felt like I had a tool from the heavens in my hand gliding across my face. I seriously did not expect my first shave to go this smooth with a de, and I ended up going against the grain (which I stopped doing a while ago with that useless fusion since all those blades were just pulling way too much), and it came out to be one of the best shaves I've ever given myself. Cheeks were smooth as a baby's bottom, and the irritation wasn't a problem at all. Just threw on a little Brut and some moisturizer and all was good. If a first timer like myself can use this thing without any cuts at all, anybody can. The whole process took a little longer than my usual shave, but it was my first time and I wanted to be extra careful. But the smooth shave is definitely worth the extra time and patience, trust me. Feather blades and this razor make one awesome combination. It's just amazing how good this is, and it's only my first day...I have much to learn. If your even thinking about buying this, go ahead and make that purchase, you won't regret it for $20 or so out your pocket.

It was still perfectly usable and provided a good shave, but I tossed it before its condition got any worse. The price ranges vary wildly, but you can likely find something like a nice Gillette Super Speed for ~$15.

  510. I'm accustomed to and have been generally happy shaving with:<br /><br />1. [[ASIN:B003BVINRW Schick Hydro 3 Blade Razor]]<br />2. [[ASIN:B002O7UI18 C.O. Bigelow Premium Shave Cream with Eucalyptus Oil 147g/5.2oz]]<br />3. [[ASIN:B003WR3QSG Escali 100% Pure Badger Shaving Brush]]<br /><br />However, purchasing replacement cartridges has become increasingly expensive, causing me to look into alternatives.<br /><br />After researching a variety of options, I decided to try the safety razor experience. I considered several entry-level options under $20, as I didn't want to invest too heavily before knowing whether I really wanted to commit to this change or not. One of the main reasons I chose the Feather Double Edge was because of its butterfly hinge head and the Feather brand. Other razors in this price range utilize a screw-top assembly. Based on their product reviews, it seems that the threading of that assembly stripped rather easily (within several months), rendering the razor useless. It also appeared to me that the butterfly hinge would facilitate a quicker blade change.<br /><br />The product arrived with a plastic box/carrying case, two Feather blades, and a plastic blade dispenser.<br /><br />Here's a summary of my experience with the Feather Double Edge so far:<br /><br />(NOTE: Please take into account that I and my skin are still adjusting to this new style!)<br /><br />PROS<br />+ Much cheaper than cartridge razors<br />+ Butterfly hinge top enables quick blade change<br />+ Overall weight balance seems very good; weight in the head helps achieve the correct angle for shaving<br />+ Product quality good, given the price<br /><br />CONS<br />- Increased likelihood of razor burn in specific places (more likely due to my inexperience with the razor than any fault of the razor itself)<br />- Shave does not seem to be as consistently close as with the Hydro 3 (again, likely due to inexperience)<br /><br />All in all, I am initially quite satisfied. The Feather Double Edge has given me what I feel to be a solid introduction to the world of safety razors and look forward to becoming more skilled in using it and trying out different blades to discover the right combination for me and my skin.

  515. I purchased this razor to replace an Edwin Jagger that I accidentally dropped and the handle had sheared off at the head. I love Feather's blades, and have enjoyed using this razor. It is much more forgiving than the Edwin Jagger that I owned previously, though you can certainly still cut yourself if you aren't careful. I love the opening/closing mechanism for the blade. It is very quick and simple to replace one, particularly compared to the Jagger. You can have the blade out and clean it and have it back in place in a matter of seconds.

I did not have a mirror and I ran out of hot water in about two minutes, so the whole plan broke down pretty fast. That is what I figure will make the amazing shave I have on my left (started there) side be my whole face shave. Oh, and ideally have a mirror.   521. This is my first double edge safety razor, so I did a fair amount of research before purchasing. I knew I wanted something relatively user friendly and not too expensive--on the off chance that I hated it.<br /><br />I went back and forth on this one, my main concern stemmed from having noticed a lot of people complaining about it being partially plastic. Though now I have to say, I think that is one of the things I like best about it. The plastic bits mean that it is not as heavy as the more pricey models, which facilitates a nice transition for someone who is switching from standard disposables or cartridge razors.<br /><br />I definitely think this is a good choice for beginners, as it is not at all difficult to figure out how to use. My one word of warning would be to make sure the twist mechanism is tightened down snug before every shave. Not that I am implying that it loosens with use. It doesn't. I'm just saying, if you think it's tight and it's not, the blade will wobble and you absolutely will get cut. In fact, despite being a newbie to this style of razor, that scenario is the only time I have gotten cut.<br /><br />As far as the actually shaving goes, ladies, if you are concerned at all about trying this sort of razor, don't be. Just buy one. Equally suitable for legs, underarms, and bikini area; I can say without any doubt that this provides the closest, smoothest shave I've ever had. And most importantly, since I started using this razor I've not had to deal with ANY razor burn or bumps. Which, for me, is a definite first.

You could spend lots of time trying to wash the soap and whiskers from between the blades. They very quickly got dull and missed half of the whiskers leaving UN-shaven areas on your face. I grew up using one of these and have no idea why I fell for the sales pitch from the razor manufactures. I think purchasing this razor and the giant blade package will last me the rest of my life. I have shaved 4 times with this item using the, same blade and it still is doing a nice job of shaving. This Double Edge razor is by far the best and cheapest way to shave. The quality of this item is excellent. I prefer an all metal razor but it is difficult to find a quality item that is all metal. There are several here on Amazon.com but the reviews were not of my liking. I believe I have made the right choice in this item as it performs extremely well and is easy to open and clean the whiskers from the blade area.
  536. The quality price ratio was very attractive. These type of razors are my favorite and are cheaper in the long run.
  537. Its still under the tree until sat night, but it was a great buy and he will love it, if he doesn't buy that one the Pawn Stars guy keeps hawking on the commercials!
  538. I jumped into the DE market feet first and went with a heavyweight Chrome plated razor (Edwin Jagger De89bl Double Edge Safety Razor Chrome) that was on back-order. I heard great things about feather razor blades and decided to get this razor in the mean time and for travel. I must say this is a great razor and perfect pairing for the feather blades. When my fancy razor came in I had to switch back to the feather because it was much more forgiving and provided a faster and safer shave for me. In short this is the perfect razor to learn or travel with. I'm going to eventually try my classic chrome one again but am afraid the feather has spoiled me. Great Japanese engineering and seems to be sturdy enough. Plus you can't beat the price!
  539. I wanted a cleaner and smother shaved look. Feather offers a great product at a great price. Multiple blade razors are over rated. This is all any man needs to get the clean, smooth look others will notice.
  540. Quite a newbie to this DE Shaving Malarky. Been at it only 4 weeks. Now I only own 2 DE razors (this and a Weishi/Commoy) , but this this the best. It's an Excellent Razor and feels just right in the hand. As recommended I bought a sample pack of razor blades to test out as everyone has their own personal preferences. I was really surprised to find out that its the Astra Platinum and the Gillette 7 O'Clock blades that suit my particular mug. I had less success with the Merker blades and the &#34;Everyone Raves About&#34; Feather blades (where the styptic pencil proved handy).<br /><br />Maybe this will change with better technique and time. From using an Electric and Mach 3 I'm pretty sure I won't go back to these more costly (but less effective items). Its weird when you go &#34;old school&#34; you actually enjoy the shaving experience. :-)
  541. I bought this as an inexpensive travel razor, but have been very disappointed. My other razor is a Merkur 180 long handle, and this does not come anywhere close to it. First, it is mostly plastic, though it is &#34;good&#34; plastic it is still inconsistent in critical dimensions. Most importantly it does not provide a close shave, and every time I use it I end up nicking and scraping because I try to make up for it by pressing too hard and going over the same spot multiple times. Spend the extra money and get one that is all metal and quality construction.

  548. I've tried 4 safety razors in the course of a few months of trying out different combinations of razors and blades (Derby, Feather, and Astra blades are what I've tried). This Feather Razor is the best of all of them - plus the Feather blades are incredibly sharp as everybody had said. I give this combination 5 stars, but I still am going to have to go back to shaving with my Hydro 3 blades or the Dorco blades that are even less expensive. These double-edge razors tear my neck up, and it takes so long to shave with them that I just can't use them anymore. This product is the best one of what I have, though, because I like the lighter and longer shaft that lets me put as much pressure on my face as I want to.

  562. This razor gives me a very fine shave, but it is very light weight, and has some plastic parts, so I am not sure how durable it is going to be. The light weight can be a benefit for some, when using the ultra sharp Feather blades, as it makes more noise when cutting, and you can feel the feedback in your hand. Might need to put some protection around it when travelling, as airlines always try to turn baggage into pulp. At the price though, if was the perfect razor for me, I'd probably get several to have as backups. I prefer my heavier Parker razor, still with Feather blades.

  566. My first safety razor and it does the job well. It is not as heavy as some that I have felt, but you still do not need much pressure. The blades that come with the razor are VERY sharp. They are more forgiving than I expected, but you will get some irritation if your technique is wrong. I recommend some good soap or cream when using the Feather blades. When you finish with the two Feather blades I recommend Van Der Hagen blades. They work well on medium hair and are pretty forgiving about technique. If you have really thick hair then I would stick with the Feather blades. My friend says Van Der Hagen tug too much for him.<br /><br />All in all if you are wanting to start using safety razors, you can't go wrong with this one.
  567. I love this razor. It's plenty long for my big man hands and gets the job done. I just wish the edge of the razor stuck out a tiny bit farther, but nonetheless I would buy this again, and I definitely recommend. Shipping was good also.

Even the box is sturdy, convenient and easy to open and close.<br /><br />This thing leaves my skin smooth, no sign of stubble.   580. First, I have very coarse facial hair. I have been using the over-priced Fusion cartridges since they came out, because they worked &#34;the best.&#34; Whoa was I ever wrong.   586. I have 4 double-edge Razors & this one is my overall favorite. The handle texture makes it non-slip & the extra-long handle works well with large hands,
  587. Let’s start by acknowledging that this is not intended to be, marketed as (or priced) as a first-class razor. It’s advertised as ‘combining affordability with performance’, and that’s probably about right. If you want twice the razor, get yourself a nice Merkur for about twice the price (search for Merkur Double-Edge Razor right here on Amazon.com; you’ll find several nice ones). That said, if you’re just starting out in Double Edged razor shaving and don’t want to spend a lot, or if you’re looking to take your wet-shaving on the road and just want a lightweight DE razor to toss into your travel shave kit, this razor is worth the money.<br /><br />On the plus side, if you use a good blade (I use Feather blades) this razor will give you a decent shave.<br /><br />A ‘minus‘ to me - and it may not be a negative to everyone - is that this razor holds the blade at a much less aggressive angle than the Merkur razors I use. Look at the pictures of the Merkur razors here on Amazon and you’ll see a pronounced curve to their tops; that curved top closes down on the blade, bending it over to achieve a fairly aggressive cutting angle. That angle seems to give me a closer shave. This Feather razor is flatter at the top, consequently it does not bend the razor blade as much and the cutting angle is not as great. Again, the sharper angle is the one my face prefers; this razor’s angle may feel better to you. (I’ve looked at some of the other reviews since I first wrote this, and indeed other reviewers DO feel that this razor’s angle works better for them. So it really is a matter of personal preference.)<br /><br />The other thing to be aware of is that this is, as advertised, a razor made largely of plastic. That saves weight (again, good for travel), but feels less solid in your hand - because it is. That’s not necessarily bad, it just is what it is.<br /><br />This is a moderately priced DE razor, and it will give you a moderately good shave. I recommend it for those who may not want to spend a lot on their first DE razor, or for experienced DE shavers who may looking for a lighter razor and are willing to give up a little bit of closeness in their shave in return. I use if for that reason, and it’s not a bad tradeoff.
  588. Great razor. My tough beard tamed by included Feather blades. If you are new to single blade shaving...you will be pleasantly surprized. Save some cash and some plastic from the landfills.
  589. Awesome price and quality! I used this razor the day it arrived and had the best shave in a long time. You won't be disappointed.
  590. decent razor. I thought it would be great to use with feather blades, but the razor overall is just ok. I prefer the parker 99r
  591. It is a cheap razor, but well made for the price... maybe adding $20 could get you a better one.
  592. I read several reviews prior to purchasing. The Feather razor fits my hands and is easy to use. The Feather blades are sharp and I was able to shave without any nicks. I think some of the other reviews about nicks with these blades were by novices who had never shaved before with a DE razor. I like the fact that I can easily clean the razor and blade is a big plus for me. I remove the blade after each shave and run hot water over both the blade and open razor head. No more crud as between the multi-bladed razors.

  603. For me this is the first DE razor I have bought after reading a lot of reviews online about various types of DE's.<br /><br />The plastic aspect of this razor was the only hesitation I had at first to purchasing this razor, but after receiving and using the razor, the plastic doesn't take away from the quality at all. I bought more feather blades, as again I have looked a lot and they are the best apparently i.e. the sharpest. My whiskers are like barbed wire sticking out of my face for my daily shave, and need something super sharp to pass through, and since feather is the sharpest, thats what I went with.<br /><br />Don't be afraid and give this DE a shot, buy with confidence.
  604. I was between the $3 chinese double edge or the $32 edwards before I found these. Really glad I went with these. Quality made, locks everything in tight, has a nice buffer, not too hard to use. Recommended for all.
  605. I really like grooming so I decided to switch from my electric razor in order to add aftershave to my morning routine. Since switching, my relationship has improved, I got a promotion, and my cat sits on my lap more. Also, now I start small talk with strangers about the art of using a safety razor and how it's so much better than every other method of shaving. If they mention that they use an electric or quintuple bladed Gillette, I laugh. I laugh in their poorly shaved faces. Buy this razor and join me today.
  606. I've only ever used a cartridge razor or occasional electric so this is my first safety razor. Watched a few videos where they talked about it taking 10 minutes to use a safety razor when you get used to it including warming the blade, messing with a bristle brush and foaming up the shaving cream. I skipped most of that and just used a little gel out of a can. I shave in the shower at the end. On the first stroke it wasn't clear I was even touching my face as I could hardly feel it. I just use my cartridge method with the safety razor, first with the grain, then against. Right side, left side, center. Done. No nicks, no pull, no chin or Adam's apple problem. It took only a few minutes. Way easier than the youtube videos made it out to be.<br /><br />I should have tried this years ago. The wife thinks it is closer than the cartridge 4 blade razor and orders of magnitude more economical. I don't know anything about less or more aggressive shaves but I cannot imagine much better than this. I don't see any need to pay up for a safety razor more expensive than this. The 10 blades that came with this are going to last a while.
  607. I decided to switch back to DE safety razors after about a 20 year hiatus due to the constantly escalating price of my Fusion cartridges. With the \\"fog of time\\", I actually don't remember why I switched to cartridges in the first place; but, boy, am I happy that I switched back! This razor is very lightweight and simple, but does its job really well with zero nicks and cuts with my first two shaves. I used the stock Feather blades that came with the razor and they seem to pair up well together. The blade is angled quite a bit and the razor is very \\"non-aggressive\\". I found that I can shave much faster than I can with my Fusion razor and I get a closer, smoother shave much quicker. I use the razor both with the grain and against it (yes, I know that it is not recommended) and it seems to work really well both ways. One minor quibble is that the handle feels a bit short in my large mitts and the razor feels slightly top heavy compared to my old metal DE razors whose handles were more heavy, which gave them a bit more balance. However, this did not detract from the use of the razor in any way. After this experience, I cannot see myself going back to my cartridge razor anytime soon (other than instances where TSA will not allow me to carry DE razor blades in my carry-on luggage!) For the price I paid for this razor, it seems like an absolute steal, with made-in-Japan quality in both the razor and the blades. I intend to keep using the Feather blades going forward since they seem to match up really well with the razor.
  608. Returned to shaving with double edge safety razors, puck and brush in May 2013, after 40 years of shaving with disposable blades. Woke up one day and nostalgia hit me in the center of my forehead. Did not want to spend a lot of $ on a safety razor not knowing if I could regain the safety razor technique and being unsure how my face and neck would react. So, the Feather Double Edge Shaving Razor combined with a sampler pack of safety blades were inexpensive choices. The razor is high on my value to cost scale. No issues with the razor. I settled on Wilkinson double edge blades. My combination yields a close shave while saving me a bunch of bucks over disposables. Will soon begin experimenting with different brands of pucks.

  618. I've been using this razor for a couple of weeks now and cannot complain about the quality of the build. It seems to be adequate and modern plastics can be quite strong. My problem is that the shave is not nearly as close as I get with the Merkur 180 razor.<br /><br />From reading the reviews, I think my problem may be with not finding the correct blade angle. I have been shaving for 50+ years with both double edge and cartridge razors and may have established a pattern too hard to break as far as blade angle is concerned. I have tried to vary the angle and still do not seem to get a close shave. I have been using the Feather blades that came with the razor. I have medium to medium-light facial hair.<br /><br />I started shaving with DE razors around 1960 or so, and moved to cartridge razors when they came out many years later. About a month ago I went in to buy cartridge blades and saw the price of $28.00 for a package of five or six and said \\"This is ridiculous!\\" I decided to go back to DE blades at less than 1/10 of the price. So I ordered the Merkur 180 and the Feather razor from Amazon. Neither razor has cut or nicked me, but I just cannot make the Feather shave as closely as the Merkur.<br /><br />Perhaps if you have very light facial hair or are just starting to learn how to use a DE razor the Feather will work fine for you. For me, however, the blade angle designed into the razor seems so mild that I cannot get it give the really close shave that the Merkur will produce.
  619. I am actually a woman who was REALLY tired of spending $15 a pop on like four of those mach 3 razors. Even though I got many multiple shaves from a single cartridge, it was still just way too expensive. I love my smooth legs, but razors designed for women are COMPLETE TRASH. They don't shave anything well, regardless of hair texture, in my experience. So, that all said, this razor setup has been great for me. BUT, I have to knock off a star, because I have had rust inside of this thing. It isn't a lot, and it may be partially the blades, but if you don't get this thing completely dry afterwards, yeah.. I've had some rust in it. It's superficial, but it's there. I am using stainless feather blades, so it's not that I'm using crap blades. I try not to leave it damp, either, I open it up and pat everything dry with a towel, blade included, both sides. But it's hard to dry out some of the small areas.
  620. I have been using a Gillette Eveready safety razor for years. I bought this razor as a travel replacement to keep my good razor at home.   626. This razor is way too small for my large hand, can only use a few fingers, therefore not a good fit nor shave. Took over a month to arrive.
  627. First of all, let me say that I believe ProGlide is outstanding. Best cartridge out there -- and I've tried them all. At the same time, I took a chance on the Feather Double-Edge Razor simply because I was getting tired of plopping down over $17 for a 4-pk of ProGlide cartridges. I'm glad I did! This Feather produces the closest, best shave I have ever experienced. That good. It took me a couple of shaves to get the right angle down pat. No biggie. I'm now on shave #6 with the same blade. Great blade. Sharp but I'm getting no nicks or irritation. That was my biggest worry about going with a double-edge razor. Look, we're all different. I can only go by what I've been experiencing. Bottom line: I'm never going back to the cartridges.
  628. I ordered this before seeing the Edwin Jagger razor which I also ordered. This doesn't have the weight of the other, and I am actually able to control the other razor better. Still, it's not bad, and I will keep it and use it as a travel razor. Feather blades were too sharp in this razor, and it did a better job using Shark blades, which also work well with my better razor.
  629. Excellent value. Shaves nearly flawlessly. A must have for anyone with sensitive skin. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a good razor.
  630. I must confess that the Feather razor was my third choice. I'd bypassed it because I felt that the name 'Feather' wasn't appropriate for a man's razor. (Silly reason.) So I ordered a Weishi (plastic) razor, but when I found it was going to take a month to come all the way from China, I ordered the USRazor, which came in a week or so. However, there was a problem in that the bar that locates the blade was a bit too thin, so the blade could be exposed unevenly. The result was a harsh shave using one side, and no shave using the other side of the blade. And it could be secured at an angle, which was worse. When the Weishi came I found it too short and seemingly lighter than the old disposables. I went back to the customer reviews -- mostly because the Feather had won a four-and-a-half star rating -- but it was a comment by K. Cummings in the first customer review that prompted me to try the Feather. He made a point that the blade seated perfectly in the razor, and he was right! The razor came in the predicted time and my first shave was both comfortable and close. Another factor was the favorable comparison to the old Gillette razors mentioned by many reviewers. I'll be turning 77 in May, and have been shaving for over 60 years, and frankly I find it BORING, so trying a double-edged razor was more for the sake of variety than the cost of disposables, but my thanks go to Mr. Cummings for his input. It was most appreciated. And this review is as much for his comments as for the excellent razor.
  631. Husband loves the razor. Easy to handle, long with grooves on it to prevent slipping.<br />good shave. recommends this razor
  632. I own several metal razors sold by Merkur, Edwin Jagger, Parker, and Baxter of California. All of them are high-quality razors, and each has its advantages and disadvantages. I have used Feather blades and was curious to try this Feather razor to see if a lighter razor might be easier to use.<br /><br />The razor arrives nicely packaged in a clear plastic storage box. A small pack of Feather blades is included, and the storage box has a nice storage compartment built-in to keep a box of blades handy with the razor if used for traveling.<br /><br />The razor itself if made almost entirely of plastic with the head and turning knob the only metal parts. The plastic does give the razor a cheap look and feel to it, just like plastic disposable razors, but it also makes the razor very lightweight. The head of the razor has a butterfly mechanism that opens up when the knob at the top of the handle is turned. This allows very safe and easy cleaning of both the razor and blade after shaving. There is nothing to disassemble. The butterfly head stays closed without needing to repeatedly tighten the knob while shaving, which sometimes occurs with other razors I have used.<br /><br />I have used this razor with different brands of blades including one of the included Feather blades. All have yielded a close, comfortable shave with this razor. The plastic bumper at the edge of the razor seems to add protection against nicks and cuts better than my metal razors. The razor's light weight also makes it a lot more controllable, which I think also lessens the risk for cuts. I have arthritic hands, and this razor is a lot more comfortable to hold due to its lighter weight. Those used to shaving with a double-edged blade know that a light touch is needed for comfortable, nick-free shaving. This Feather razor makes that light touch very simple.<br /><br />If you are new to double-edged blade shaving or are experienced and simply want an inexpensive razor for travel or daily usage, this Feather razor is definitely worth owning. It is an excellent choice for anyone with arthritic hands. It may look and feel cheap, but it handles well, provides a close shave just as well as more expensive razors, and is very easy to maintain. With its included plastic storage case it makes for an ideal travel razor.usage, this Feather razor is definitely worth owning. It is an excellent choice for anyone with arthritic hands. It may look and feel cheap, but it handles well, provides a close shave just as well as more expensive razors, and is very easy to maintain. With its included plastic storage case it makes for an ideal travel razor.

I open it up and remove the blade and use an old toothbrush to clean it with, then leave the razor out to dry. It comes in a plastic case, which can be used for storing the razon on the shelf and two Feather blades, which do a great job of shaving and are sharp. This razor works and does what it was designed to do and you don't really need anything better unless you just want to say that you have a $150.00 razor. For $20.00 you can't go wrong. And last but most defiantly not least you don't have to take the whole head off to put in a new blade you just twist the handle and the top opens right up you put the new one, twist the handle and you are ready to go.
  642. I was tired of paying $4 a 5-blade cartridge, even though they gave what I thought was a good shave. I looked into safety razors and double-edged blades as an alternative, and decided to give them a try. I settled on the Feather razor, as it was budget priced, and from the reviews, it was not extremely aggressive--meaning that it positions the blade so as to minimize cutting yourself, at the expense of getting the ultimate close shave. I felt that as a new-comer to this old-school method, that this was a prudent trade-off. I turned out to be right.<br /><br />This razor, paired with the super sharp Feather brand blades have given me a closer shave than I have ever experienced, and I have not cut myself seriously even once. I have been very mindful about the possibility of a mishap, but even while using extreme caution, I am able to get a shave that, 12 hours later, feels as close as the best shave I was able to get out of the cartridge system I had been using.<br /><br />I have what I consider a fairly thick, coarse beard, and I don't have a perfect complexion, but by going first with the grain, and then re-applying my shaving cream and making a careful pass against the grain, I have had stellar results. The blades are sharp enough to glide smoothly no matter the direction, and the razor is constructed so that I don't get cut even when trying to get close under nose, or shaving in the cleft of my chin. Initially--for about the first week of every day use--I was getting a little irritation, but that has subsided. I do get a few tiny nicks, but I have had that with every razor I've ever used. I have an alum bar but have found it mostly unnecessary, and possibly more aggravating than the shave. I just rinse with cool water, then apply a little mild witch hazel skin toner, and my face is smooth, soft and comfortable.<br /><br />This is a budget razor, and is mostly plastic, but given that, still seems of above average quality. It is not heavy, but has a good balance, and a long handle to accommodate any grip. I definitely would recommend it to someone starting out with safety-razor shaving.<br /><br />Bottom Line: Low initial cost, safe and easy shaving, and great results.
  643. Been 60 years since I had one of these. Forgot what a truly great shave they give.<br />Only one thing wrong. I ordered a mug and shave soap and forgot the brush. :)<br />Waiting to get another order together to add that.
  644. I am on my second shave and it is the smoothest I've had since a straight razor shave. I did manage to nick my nose this evening, but in a place I had already nicked with my cartridges. The feather blades worked out great despite my friends all assuring me that I would be left with a mangled face. Looking forward to years of great shaves.

  664. Great product, great price. Might just be my face/beard, but this one shaves wonderfully for mine, while more expensive ones did not. Made me a fan of Feather products and blades.
  665. I first used a DE razor as an adolescent in the 70's but soon the proliferation of disposables and the development of cartridge razors made them obsolete. As the decades went by I went from cartridge blades featuring 2 blades to 3 blades to the ridiculous and over priced 5 blade models, all the while paying ever increasing prices for those designs, up to the tune of $5 a blade. Then I had begun evaluating the expense of these \\"miracle\\" cartridge shavers and decided to try the DE shaving system once again, if not for merely nostalgia then to pay only ~.35 cents a blade versus five bucks.<br /><br />My first attempts failed miserably. I ended up with a satisfactory shave on the face, but on the throat and below the jaw I found shaving with a DE razor more akin to losing a battle with a sword wielding Ninja. I went back to cartridges for some years after, deciding \\"nostalgia\\" shaving technology was best left in the past where it originated.<br /><br />After hearing a co-worker talk about his satisfaction with DE's and more research on the 'net, I decided to attempt this \\"new-old\\" shaving system once more. Realizing my past failures, I knew I needed to do something different. My skin is not super-sensitive, but not sheet leather either. What had I done wrong before? I soon began to find the answers.<br /><br />The problem I realized, is that cartridge razors teach you to shave \\"incorrectly\\". Due to the fact they are essentially a blade or set of blades that are set into a box at a 30-40 degree angle or so (that's my guess), you are forced to place the shaving implement flat against your face for them to work. Couple that with their tendency to accumulate junk between the blades and you must increase pressure to maintain sufficient blade-skin contact. They do work adequately when employed as their design dictates, but the technique they force you to use is disastrous if transferred to a DE razor.<br /><br />I purchased this Feather model DE and wasn't particularly impressed with it out of the box. Though well made in appearance, it was predominantly plastic. Aren't DE razors supposed to be metal and super heavy? The handle of about 4 inches appealed to me though. I knew with use of razors with stubby 3 inch handles I did not have the degree of control (unbalanced to me) I needed. I loaded a brand new Feather DE razor blade in it and vowed the next morning I would shave with it, but in doing so throw out the window everything the cartridge razor system had taught me. I knew I would have to \\"re-learn\\" how to shave to make this system work.<br /><br />For one, the plastic construction actually works for me much better than the purported benefits of the heavy weight metal models by increasing my control of the unit. What I discovered was that the additional handle length acted less as a gripping surface and more of a counter balance to the weight of the blade bearing head as I held the razor primarily between thumb, index and middle fingers. I decided I preferred the butterfly opening top instead of the removable cap some designs sport.<br /><br />Use a good shave cream. This is as personalized a choice as any, but a good quality shave cream is essential. Quality shave cream is a crucial friction reducer as the blade glides over skin. I prefer a canned cream such as Barbasol Aloe. Avoid the gimmicky, razor clogging gels.<br /><br />Blade angle. I maintained as well as possible a blade-to-skin angle of approximately 40-ish degrees, maybe slightly less.<br /><br />NO PRESSURE. I repeat, none. Cartridge razors encourage the application of pressure to maintain blade-skin contact and this is a bad habit cartridge blade users often carry over to their first efforts with a DE razor. There is no need to apply pressure with a DE razor. The blade is there, not inset below a box frame, so it does its work without requiring any pressure to efficiently slice your stubble.<br /><br />Short, even strokes. With box cartridge razors I had developed thebad habit of dragging the razor from ear to chin in one continuous stroke. Do not do this with a DE razor. Gradually work your way down (or up) in short, light strokes, maintaining and adjusting your blade angle as appropriate.<br /><br />Second passes. Never make a second pass (such as against the grain) without re-applying shave cream to that area. Another bad habit I had developed with cartridge razors I found I needed to break in order to succeed with a DE razor.<br /><br />Whenever possible, stretch skin flat and taught. When this is more difficult to do (around the throat in particular), make your strokes even MORE light and short. This technique alone will reduce or eliminate the vast majority of nicks and abrasions.<br /><br />Take your time! If you don't have the time, wait until you do to practice. Though once you have committed your technique to memory it will become second nature, avoid the initial temptation to treat DE shaving like it's a 2 minute and done cartridge razor shaving session.<br /><br />When choosing a DE system, expect to have to buy a few different brands of razors, blades and creams before you hit on the combo that works best for you. I did, and I stopped looking after buying this Feather and the Feather blades.<br /><br />I am now done with cartridge razors. Some may find the transition is easy, others will not, but no doubt when used correctly they are a highly efficient and extremely cost effective alternative to the \\"miracle\\" super duper, twisting, rotating, vibrating, pivoting razor marketing gimmicks pitched to shavers around the world at a substantial expense to your shaving budget.ke. Do not do this with a DE razor. Gradually work your way down (or up) in short, light strokes, maintaining and adjusting your blade angle as appropriate. Second passes. Never make a second pass (such as against the grain) without re-applying shave cream to that area. Another bad habit I had developed with cartridge razors I found I needed to break in order to succeed with a DE razor. Whenever possible, stretch skin flat and taught. When this is more difficult to do (around the throat in particular), make your strokes even MORE light and short. This technique alone will reduce or eliminate the vast majority of nicks and abrasions. Take your time! If you don't have the time, wait until you do to practice. Though once you have committed your technique to memory it will become second nature, avoid the initial temptation to treat DE shaving like it's a 2 minute and done cartridge razor shaving session. When choosing a DE system, expect to have to buy a few different brands of razors, blades and creams before you hit on the combo that works best for you. I did, and I stopped looking after buying this Feather and the Feather blades. I am now done with cartridge razors. Some may find the transition is easy, others will not, but no doubt when used correctly they are a highly efficient and extremely cost effective alternative to the \\"miracle\\" super duper, twisting, rotating, vibrating, pivoting razor marketing gimmicks pitched to shavers around the world at a substantial expense to your shaving budget.
  666. I decided to go back to the old way of shaving with mixing my own shaving cream with a cake and a brush, and shaving with the type of razor my dad and his dad used. All of the new high tech razors with their multiple blades and high costs aren't worth the money. This razor works perfectly and provides a better and closer shave than anything I've tried. It is priced right for someone wanting to get back to the old style (there are others on-line costing much more). The only thing I would do differently is order addition blades when ordering the razor. It comes with blades but only two in the package and you'll need others on hand. I'm still on a learning curve with it all but it seems a week of daily shaves is the life of a blade - the sharper they are, the better the shave.

Really the only thing I would change is the case it comes in. Made of cheap plastic & not pretty at all, but still, even after months of constant use, it's held up without breaking, so I can't really complain, given the price. I will ALWAYS prefer my straight blade over any other razor, but when the scales on my straight razor needed to be replaced, or when I'm running behind and don't have time to shave with a straight razor, this thing does the job. I will NEVER touch my face with another multi-blade piece of crap again!

  680. made well and looks really sharp. I threw away the sample blades it came with since I tried one and it cut me even though I took my time shaving.   681. I don't want to duplicate other more extensive reviews. A few things you might be interested in: First, the razor feels solid and very well-made. It has a good sturdy feel to it, without feeling heavy at all. Second, the mechanism actually bends the razor blade down at the cutting edges, while it is higher in the middle. This changes the angle of the razor blade where it contacts your skin--it points more toward the handle than you might expect. I've been getting good shaves from this. I think the razors themselves might be a tad too sharp, or aggressive for me. Either because the blade has dulled or because I've gotten better, my third and fourth shaves with the blade have been the best.
  682. It works, good razor.
  683. Great Shaver! Awesomely priced!
