  698. My only experience with double edged razors was watching my grandpa do it when I was child. I've used disposable or electric razors the past 35 years. Neither product ever really provided what I assumed other people thought of as a &#34;clean shave&#34;. I nearly always cut myself, left areas of my face rough and with disposables had to go through the shame of buying replacement heads at $15-$20 a pop like some hamster on a manufacturer's recurring revenue hamster wheel. So while shopping on Amazon yet again for replacement heads for a disposable razor that I hoped the manufacturer hadn't discontinued I came across double edged razors. So I decided to give it a try. I looked up how to use a double edged razor on youtube and then bought this low cost razor from a quality manufacturer figuring if it I didn't like it I would only be out $20 for the effort. After a month the results have been impressive. My face is as clean and smooth as a baby's butt. I've nicked myself a couple of times, but less than when using a disposable razor (styptic pencil on standby). This razor holds the blade solidly, glides smoothly over my craggy face and cleans up well (something that disposables never seem to do without pounding them against the sink until they break). I'm sure a more expensive double edged razor would be even better, but I'm satisfied with this razor and will continue to use it until it stops performing as well as it has been. So if you're thinking about trying double edged razors but don't want to spend $100-$200 to find out you don't like it, then this is your product. BTW - I use Remington's King of Shaves Alphagel. For my face there is no other gel or cream that even comes close to providing a clean shave like I've described. So even if I go back to disposables, the Aphagel is coming with me.
  699. This is the worst razor and worst shave I've ever had. I keep hearing all these amazing things from friends about switching to safety razors and dumping the Gilette over priced garbage. Well this particular razor and handle is not worth it at all. Find a better one, and a sharper blade.
  700. good just not as good as one might expect. my face cant handle close shaves or at least with my shaving expiertise. still a nice bang for your buck.
  701. It sure is better than the expensive multiblade razors sold by the brand name companies.
  702. First time trying a double edge razor after using cartridge razors over 30 years. I love it. Razor is great quality, not too agressive and is priced right.
  703. I decided to start using DE razors because I was sick if the cost if multi-blade cartridges that couldn't cut a clean edge to my goatee, mustache, and sideburns. I didn't want to invest a lot of money on a &#34;starter&#34; razor so I chose this. I get a decent shave with thist using a 4 pass technique. The feather blades are sharp! After a few weeks I'm looking into a razor upgrade, something with more weight and a more aggressive shaving action. All that being said I feel this is a good razor to see if you like the DE experience.
  704. When I first opened the package I was disappointed until I put a blade in and had my first shave. I'd been using an old razor that I've had since the 80's and this was a good replacement.<br /><br />My only disappointment, and it's just a preference, but I like a razor with a little &#34;heft&#34;, but this is my new daily and it works great.
  705. This is my first DE shaver, and I really like it! Yes, the handle does have a tiny bit of plastic, but the most important parts are metal. Also the unit might look like some cheap junk in the package picture here, but it does not feel cheap at all. In fact it feels very high quality to me. And after using it, I actually like the unit being partially plastic because it helps keep the weight down, which is already pretty hefty as it is. I highly recommend it.
  706. Most inexpensive items don't hold up or just don't have the 'fit and finish' you're looking for. My last razor lasted 10 years but it was a $100 razor. For the rather low cost, I really didn't expect much. I've been quite impressed! lightweight and the adjustor to open it up and replace blades works smoothly. A great value.
  707. I really like this razor. It is much lighter than my Edwin Jagger. So I pair it up with Feather blades and use it as my travel razor--got the leather case too. Love it.
  708. This razor works well, I have noticed that people on you tube have had to run 2 or 3 completed re-shaves when using shaving cream. Because I use Bump Patrol, which is a clear slimy lubrication, I only have to do one complete shave. This is a good shaving razor. Hard to get just under my nose though.
  709. I have one of those beards that is more like a wire brush. I have been known to ruin multi-blades razors with just one use. So I decided to go back to the old double edge razor blade.   711. Awesome! Lightweight and easy to use.
  712. This is a unique razor. I would not want to have it as my only razor, but I would really miss it if I didn't have it.<br /><br />Shave is exceedingly mild and for me requires PERFECT blade angle in order to get closest shave, especially if my beard is on the long side at the time. Because of this, I wouldn't want it as my only razor.<br /><br />But - for use as a secondary razor for touch up or polishing at the end of a shave - I love it. Just buff away and there's no skin loss or irritation.
  713. Nice razor. handle could be a bit larger for older hands.
  714. I have VERY sensitive skin and after having tried everything to stop razor burn (which for me lasted several painful days after a shave) I decided to make the change from using disposable razors with the various pre-shave/post-shave/supermarket shaving gels to an old fashioned pre-shave, cream applied with a boar brush, and this DE safety razor from Feather. I IMMEDIATELY noticed MAJOR differences over what I had experienced the past 25 years of my shaving life.<br /><br />Now, while I think using the Proraso pre-shave, cream, and post shave anti-irritation products definitely helped I know it was making the change to this type of razor that made the real difference. After reading as much info as I could about DE shaving I decided the risk was well worth it and to be honest there really was virtually ZERO risk in making the switch.<br /><br />The feather blades that come with it are incredibly sharp but this is not an aggressive razor. Held at a 30 degree angle to your face, the razor simply glides through your facial hair. Any nicks I did get on the initial shave (you do need to RE-LEARN how to shave with this) were small and honestly didn't hurt a bit as the razor is so sharp that it literally simply sliced through the imperfection - rather than pulling and grabbing on it like the 3 or 5 blade disposables I had been using.<br /><br />I've now used the razor 6 times and have had ZERO nicks, cuts, burns, ingrown, etc. - which is absolutely remarkable to me. Please take your time the first time you use it and understand NOT to use your wrist when manipulating the blade - this is what causes cuts. Lock your wrist, use your shoulder to move it up and down an inch or so at a time and turn it/rinse it frequently. Some hair will get trapped between the blade and the razor body itself so some extra careful cleaning may be needed to ensure the razors edge is fully accessible to your face. BUT - it's MUCH better than trying to clean hairs from between 3 or 5 blade disposables! AND new blades cost pennies! Saving you many dollars over the need to purchase new disposable heads!<br /><br />Making the change to the old style shave literally changed my life overnight. Using a pre-shave, good puck shave cream applied with a brush, and a DE razor has been life changing for me. (I purchased all Proraso stuff for my first go and couldn't be happier.) No more days and days of razor burn! Save a ton of money shaving the old fashioned way - your face will thank you...I promise!
  715. wow ! i get a clean shave and this razor is easy to use and to clean after the shave. the price is right to.i recomend this to anyone who wants a great shave.
  716. Had this style of razor when I was in the Corp and never failed inspections for a straggly hair left behind, don't remeber the name of razor or of blade picked up in Okinawa Japan. Lost my little razor I route to Australia and had to use the disposable razors I hated. Well I forgot of my little safety razor and happen to find a little read when I wanted to learn about a straight razor. This little guy was just the ticket and to be honest g eats used more than my straight. One word of warning take your time don't be scared of it and keep blade clean for the perfect shave. The blade I use is Feather Razor Blades NEW Hi-stainless Double Edge. Just watch it with the blades they are very sharp, if it's your first time with these razors get yourself the little pack that contains various blades. Try them out make your own decision but I will use nothing other than feather blades.<br /><br />You really don't need to fancy expensive blades, google them in comparison to single blades less stuff to worry about.<br /><br />As far as shaving cream I use neutrogena crime for sensitive skin or a homemade shaving bar of menthol shop I pick up from a artsy fartsy store.<br /><br />AGAIN be careful with the feather blades don't worry about razor just take your time.<br /> Make sure the blade in screwed down and losses death grip of the razor. You won't kill yourself shaving.<br />Avoid against the grain for a few times once you get the hang of it enjoy

  720. This razor is as good as any and for far less cost. The precision stainless steel head is of very high quality and the plastic handle is more than adequate for the job at hand. If a merger of cost and function is what you seek, look no further. This razor is durable (I've had it for over 6 months now), provides a close shave and doesn't rust. No complaints.
  721. This is an extremely well made razor - not surprising, coming from a company that makes surgical supplies. Everything about it seems very precise, and it shaves very cleanly. The only thing missing is some \\"old school\\" appeal - it doesn't have quite as much of a retro look as some of the all-metal double-edge razors. And because it has a plastic handle, it is not as heavy as an all-metal razor. But that's not a bad thing, particularly if you've become accustomed to lightweight modern razors.<br /><br />This razor is not as popular as the Parkers, Jaggers and Merkurs, but I think it's probably every bit as good as them, if not better. My analogy would be comparing a Honda Accord to a 70's muscle car. Most would admit the Accord is a better-made machine, but the muscle car has more \\"cool\\" appeal. For me, that's how it is with the Jatai. It's an excellent razor, but I'll admit the heavy, shiny all-metal razors in my medicine cabin have more retro appeal to me. (I also own a couple of Parkers, Merkurs, a Jagger, and the ridiculously cheap-but-excellent \\"Silver Tone Double Edge Blade Razor\\" from uxcell.) I end up rotating between them, because to me, they all shave equally well.<br /><br />So if you're not stuck on having the Harley Davidson appeal of a big chrome shaving implement (and/or you don't feel like investing 30+ bucks for a razor), the Jatai is an excellent investment.

  737. I have finally tossed the silly dual, tri-, quad, quint nonsense blades forever! This simple, elegant and very affordable solution will put a smile on your (well-shaved) face.<br /><br />This is a very good, and amazingly affordable, example of what is known as a 'safety razor'. I am just the right age that I remember these in my father's and grandfather's medicine chests but have never seen them for sale in the consumer commodity stores, so I had no idea what I was missing or what a ridiculous and expensive path I was being led down by the mass market shaving industry. I get, with almost exactly the same amount of effort and time, a much smoother shave. I also have said goodbye forever to the problem of clearing my razor of shaved hair. I will never go back!
  738. Fantastic razor, first one I've tried after making the switch to normal disposables. I love this razor.
  739. My first DE safety razor, I found I definitely had to take things more slowly than with cartridge razors, but it was a satisfying experience. It shaved close and feels like a sturdy product that will last a long while. Some of the youtube videos I watched about shaving with a DE razor recommended getting the blade warm, and softening the beard with hot water and soap before shaving. I tried this razor with and without doing that and it definitely makes a big difference. I'm not sure I won't buy any more cartridge razors, but I love this and plan on using it often.
  740. Goodbye expensive disposable razors! This is perfect for the everyday shaver looking to replace your expensive disposables. The first shave was perfect and I still don't even know how to properly use it. I had a few nicks but the cuts were so clean they did not bleed much at all. The &#34;plastic&#34; parts of this razor are a lot higher quality than I expected. This is definitely a keeper. Just remember it's not the same process as shaving with a disposable, but it is well worth the excellent shave this gives you and the money saved on disposables.

It is a fun ritual, but I have not yet obtained a close shave. I may need to get a straight razor.
  746. Don't buy this razor for the plastic case, it broke within the first week. The razor itself is well designed, but cheap. Handle is plastic and so is the nut. I don't anticipate this lasting very long. The parts should have been metal.

  750. My first safety razor, it took some getting used to the blade against my face. The razor itself is very lightweight in comparison to all metal safety razors. I really like the butterfly twist open type makes it simple and easy to replace the blades. The safety razor also comes with a useful plastic see through case that also holds five blades.
  751. I have shaved with an electric shaver/razor and have tried several types of \\"cartridge\\" multi-blade razors, including recent 5 blade contraptions that to me were uncomfortable to shave with. The companies that make these cartridge razors increase the price for every new blade they add. It seems at some point the quality of the shave became less important and the sales of ever more expensive cartridges became the goal.<br /><br />And they are all different, having various parts that snap together that are not compatible(between different razors). Sometimes looking at the cartridges I wondered whether they were designed to fail prematurely, spacing between the blades in some is limited and/or some plastic part would cause hair to become jammed in the crevice between the blades making the cartridge difficult to use, causing discomfort to my skin, and just failing to shave properly - result would be a need to replace the cartridge after a few uses. The price of cartridges did not go down when I used them regularly. I tried both store brand and \\"name\\" brand cartridge razors.<br /><br />During the Summer of 2011 I decided to give electric shaving a new try after using a Braun shaver/razor for some time with disappointing results about a decade ago. I bought a \\"cheap\\" Norelco 7310XL and used that together with Afta Pre-Electric lotion until recently. It gave good results, but frequently left me with razor burn on my neck(even after using the lotion).<br /><br />Electric shaving in my opinion has its strengths. The Norelco shaver/razor uses long lasting blades that are replaced after 6-12 months. This helps reduce waste and cost. The bottles of lotion lasted me several months and are recyclable. If the shaver/razor is well made and lasts a long time overall waste is reduced. That can't be said for \\"disposable\\" razors that just fill up landfills, cartridge razors are only slightly less wasteful. I was looking for a shaving product that produces low amounts of waste, producesgood results as far as shave quality, and would be relatively cheap(affordable).<br /><br />I decided to give Double Edge Safety razors a try together with \\"wet\\" shaving. This was all new to me, my grandfather used to shave this way. My father still has an old DE razor he received as a gift, with an old blade(which is like 20 years old) he virtually never uses. I wanted a newer one with a long handle. I decided to try this Feather razor with a Van Der Hagen brush, bowl, and soap kit.<br /><br />My initial cost was around $30. Which was slightly more than the cost of replacing the blades on the Norelco shaver/razor. I did not want to spend a lot of money for something that I was not sure I would use for a very long time. I really did not want to buy a more expensive Parker, Merkur, or Edwin Jagger (etc.) razor so I went with the more affordable Feather. It likely has a lower price because it has more plastic parts(than other DE razors), which will likely reduce the razor's service life. Although the moving parts appear to be made of metal(from the outside).<br /><br />I was not really expecting much in shave quality, after all, I thought to myself, this is an \\"older generation\\" of shaving technology.<br /><br />The Feather razor arrived packaged with 2 Feather Hi-Stainless blades, which seem to have a reputation for being the \\"sharpest DE blade\\". Many claim that the Feather blades are almost dangerous for beginners. I did not experience anything life threatening with these blades.<br /><br />This razor is a \\"butterfly\\" design/type. Meaning the \\"head\\" opens up(into 2 identical metal pieces) through internal machinery, which is moved by a rotating mechanism on the upper part of the handle. The head is not removed like on certain (more basic) 3 piece razor designs. This makes replacing the blade a much simpler task. There is a metal \\"retainer\\"(best way to describe it) that holds the blade in place and divides the head into 2 distinct sides.<br /><br />The handle is mostly plastic with a good grip surface which prevents you from dropping the razor. The connection point between the head and handle is also made of plastic.<br /><br />I did a few practice strokes on the neck with an un-even amount of shaving soap lather. After several shaving sessions I came to the conclusion that the Feather blade just seemed wrong for my skin(dry and easily irritated) and hair type. It left me with mild razor burn that went away after a few minutes, but made shaving my beard area somewhat uncomfortable. On my 3rd or 4th shaving session I tried a Wilkinson Sword blade, this too felt uncomfortable, plus I cut myself more often than I had with the Feather blade.<br /><br />I next moved to an Astra blade, which did not cause me as much discomfort around my beard area although I was left with some cuts. After I started using a glycerin based soap the shaving experience improved significantly. I still use the Astra blades(they work well with the glycerin soap, lasting up to 6 shaving sessions per blade), being much cheaper than Feather blades I do expect to run into some \\"bad apples\\" while using them, which I won't feel bad about replacing instantly because they are cheaper(especially when compared to cartridges).<br /><br />I developed my own shaving regimen for this razor. The neck area receives 3 passes(2 up and 1 down), the sideburns 2 passes(1 up and 1 down), mustache 2.5 passes(1 down, 1 across, and some spots receive half of an upward pass), the most tricky beard area receives 3-5 passes(1 down, several across and up). I rotate the razor to use both sides of the blade. This regimen leaves me with smooth skin for up to a day.<br /><br />One thing to note. It now takes me about 30 minutes to shave properly. I don't do it in the morning, I shave in the evening before going to sleep(it helps to take a shower beforehand to soften the hairs and skin before shaving). This gives me the maximum amount of time to shave, because if you rush with DE razors you are more likely to cut yourself and leave behind some stubble.<br /><br />The best part of Double Edge razors is that you do not feel like you are forced to conform to some Monopoly. You choose the blade you want to use, you choose the cream or soap you want to use, you choose the razor you want to use. What it could be called is \\"open source\\" shaving, like with computer software. I minimize the waste I produce - all I need to throw away are shaving soap packages(mostly paper) and used blades. I also purchased a Wilkinson Sword DE razor as an auxiliary razor.<br /><br />I recommend the Feather Double Edge razor to beginners, but the Feather blades are not for me.
  752. I've been using this for about a year. I don't use it very heavily since I only shave 2-3 times a week (I don't mind the stubble and shaving more often tends to cause people in my family trouble) and it's really only for shaving around my beard. That said, every time I use it, I take the blade out and rinse the whole thing and dry it thoroughly.<br /><br />It stands up really well to that sort of regular rigorous use of the butterfly mechanism and despite the steam from the shower, none of the parts of the razor have rusted. If I didn't want to clean and dry it that way so often, I would probably be happier with a screw-together razor but I think this will hold together fine for at least another 2-3 years.<br /><br />I didn't care for the blades that came with it and was glad I bought a 100ct. of another brand for about $8 at the same time. The one star comes off because I think it would be better to offer the razor without the \\"freebie\\" blades and at a slightly lower price.<br /><br />At any rate, shaving this way is much nicer and quite a bit cheaper than the new fashioned way.
  753. I've been thinking about coming back to double edge shaving after my own experience. I, like most of my male brethren, have been led to the false conclusion by the grooming companies that \\"more blades are better.\\" I am here to tell you that is not the case. I'll be 53 at the end of the month and my face is breaking out like it did when I was 14. Recently, I have been using 5 blade cartridges from Rite-Aid/CVS/Safeway that were inexpensive when compared to the big guys (about half price for the same count of cartridges) but that weren't as high quality. I started with the Dollar Shave Club six blade (!) alternative last month. The cost for that is $9.00 plus shipping per month for 4 carts. They aren't the best either, with a comfort strip that can barely survive 1 or 2 days and a dullness threshold that is shocking. Fortunately, with DSC, they come every month, so you can use them with some impunity.<br /><br />My face, however, continued to look like the surface of Mars. Last month, I pulled an ingrown hair from my left cheek. Needless to say, that was the last straw. After some searching on ebay and Amazon, I found this Feather double edge handle. One of the reviews here compares this handle favorably to the Gilette G1000 (The Knack). I learned on a Gilette adjustable shortly before converting to the Atra in 1977 and not looking back. I compare the Feather handle to that, except for the fact that the adjustable was not an agressive shave by any measure. I remember only nicking myself a couple of times in the two or three years of use I got out of it.<br /><br />I used the Feather this morning for the first time, It looks cheap, believe me, it isn't. The business end holds the blade perfectly and the butterfly exposes the blade just right. The handle is balanced and it is just heavy enough. If you are coming back to DE shaving, you won't have any trouble finding the right angle to shave at. If you are a beginner, watch a couple of Mantic59's YouTube videos to get the technique. I had a good first time, I did a two pass shave because when I shave every day, I have a light to moderate growth. Lately, I let myself go on the weekends (it gives my face a chance to recover) so on Monday, I generally have a heavy growth, and I can let you know then.<br /><br />Let me also comment on the quality of the blades. These guys are sharp, certainly sharper than the Personas you get from CVS. I bought an extra 10 based on reviews ([[ASIN:B001G5FOLI 10 Feather Razor Blades NEW Hi-stainless Double Edge]]) and will report on them in an update.<br /><br />I also picked up the [[ASIN:B004L4EING Van Der Hagen Men's Luxury, Shave Set]] and it's pretty good too. I'll have a review of that over there.e technique. I had a good first time, I did a two pass shave because when I shave every day, I have a light to moderate growth. Lately, I let myself go on the weekends (it gives my face a chance to recover) so on Monday, I generally have a heavy growth, and I can let you know then.<br /><br />Let me also comment on the quality of the blades. These guys are sharp, certainly sharper than the Personas you get from CVS. I bought an extra 10 based on reviews ([[ASIN:B001G5FOLI 10 Feather Razor Blades NEW Hi-stainless Double Edge]]) and will report on them in an update.<br /><br />I also picked up the [[ASIN:B004L4EING Van Der Hagen Men's Luxury, Shave Set]] and it's pretty good too. I'll have a review of that over there.
  754. I bought this after my Edwin Jagger Razor broke. I figured I could save a few bucks. Despite being mostly made of plastic the build quality of the razor seems good. Replacing a blade is very simple and fast. My big issue with the razor is that it does not shave as well as the Edwin jagger or Merkur razors I have had. I think there are 3 factors causing this: 1. it is much lighter than something like a Merkur and you can't really let the weight of the razor do the work. 2. I think the blade angle is different (less aggressive?) 3. It clogs much faster than other razors I have used. I am going to keep it for a travel razor, but I would suggest something more substantial for everyday use.
  755. A great razor and shave. A bit of nostalgia, but a good razor is a good razor. I was concerned about nicking myself, but have yet to need a styptic pencil. I prefer the shave to a double blade or other multi-bladed razor and it is much less expensive to use than others. Some things from the past deserve to live on. The razor seems well manufactured even with the plastic. I've seen no potential problems with it. It has been a very good investment.
  756. Although the razor is made of plastic, it is fairly sturdy and well put together. I have not tried other brands of blades yet, but the Feather blade that came with the razor is really sharp.<br /><br />I used to use the Gillette Mach 3 exclusively, but I got tired of the high cartridge replacement cost. This should cut my cost by half or more.<br /><br />I read about the learning curve of using a double edge razor, but it really isn't much different than using a single blade disposables. I've been shaving with this for about 2 weeks now, and so far haven't had any cuts or burns.<br /><br />That said, it is more time consuming to shave with this razor than the Mach 3, and the shave is not as close on the first pass. If it weren't for the cost factor, I would prefer the Mach 3.<br /><br />One gripe (1 star deduction) I have with the razor is that under both sides of the blade, there is a strip of plastic running perpendicular to the middle of the blade edge. Those small areas get clogged every time you shave and cannot be cleaned out by rinsing alone. You have to remove the blade and wipe it out.<br /><br />I'm just using regular canned shaving cream/gel at the moment but may try shaving soap with brush in the future.
  757. I'm honestly not sure how to rate this. I have never owned a single blade razor. It is comfortable, the weight seems to be balanced. The blade is easy to install and remove.
  758. UPDATE: The feather blades that come with the razor are fair. They last for upto 4 shaves. But after some research on the net, I discovered that Personna are even better. So, I bought a 100 count stash of Personna blades and I am very happy with them. The first one I used lasted 5 and still strong.<br /><br />By the way, as expected, I got used to the feel of a safety razor and now my shaves are taking much less time. If you are hesitating about whether you should dispose of the disposable razors forever, hesitate no more. You wont regret.<br /><br />ORIGINAL REVIEW:<br /><br />I just received my Feather DE Razor today and had my first shave about 15 minutes ago.<br /><br />First experience out of the box: It is in a plastic box that looks a bit cheap but fairly practical. It keeps the razor and the spare blades nice and tidy. So, I will keep it. The razor has a solid feel and look to it. I think it would easily survive falls on the bathroom floor from my face level.<br /><br />The shave: It was a breeze. No irritation, no cuts, no nicks. Moreover I had the closest shave in my life. But I must say, it took about twice the time I would spend using a disposable razor. Yet, the shave was so much superior and cut free that I think it is worth the effort.<br /><br />Overall: Feather DE Razor is my first safety razor, and by the looks of it, it will be my only razor for a long time. I was very reluctant to buy this razor because in my 16 years of shaving as an adult, every time I tried a razor other than simple disposable razors, I felt deeply disappointed. But Feather is supremely different. I am so happy that I gave it a chance and it is worth every penny of the price I paid for it.<br /><br />I will update this review to include information about the durability of the blades that came with it. If they keep shaving like they did just today, I will be a lifetime customer for Feather DE blades.
  759. Just got this bad boy today and had a nice shave with it. It's made of plastic, yes, but it has a very solid weight to it, and doesn't feel very cheap. The metal head is durable enough, and the safety bar is comfortable and well-positioned. A great butterfly razor for those who want a reliable shave in their day to day life. I'll keep updating this post throughout my use with the razor.
  760. I started looking into old-school safety razors because of the rapid spike in price of disposable blade cartridges. Although the handle itself was not recommended to me, the Feather brand (specifically the blades) was. Since the whole kit cost the same as a 5-pack of my normal blades, I figured I'd give it a whirl.<br /><br />This thing is amazing and worth every dollar spent on it. You know that feeling you get with a fresh blade? Shaving with this razor feels at least twice that good. I can barely feel it going across my face when even the newest disposables usually snag a little. It delivers a smooth, consistent shave, and as long as I'm careful to approach my chin from all angles it doesn't leave any stubble. The handle has enough weight to make you appreciate what you're using, but it's light enough to be easily maneuvered, and although it's double-edged I find myself consistently using just one side.<br /><br />Cleaning the razor for its next use is relatively simple as well. I find it works best if I gently wipe down the blade under running water (using the same motion one would use with a knife), rinse the handle, and then dry both with a hand towel instead of letting them air dry.<br /><br />I will admit that it does not shave as closely as a multi-blade disposable does, but for me that's a good thing. My hair, including my beard, is very curly, so razors that 'cut below the skin' leave me with a lot of bumps and general irritation. That's not a problem here; the shave I get with this razor is just close enough to look and feel great.<br /><br />Again, as the subject says, this is the Samurai sword of razors; light, sharp, and remarkably effective. You'll have a hard time finding a better shave at anywhere near the same price-point.
  761. Great product for those new to a DE safety razor. The packaging doesn't look like it has changed since the 1960s and that's a telling statement about it's success. Some have complained about the primarily plastic construction (butterfly mechanism is all metal). If there's such a s thing as premium plastic, this razor is made out of it. You could drop this off of a multi story building, use it for 40 years and then pass it on to your grandchildren. It's that good.<br /><br />Oh, and it comes with two Feather blades in the case. These things are sharp... too sharp to use for your first couple weeks of learned how to wet shave. Don't make the mistake that I did and try to use them on your first attempt. There's an art to shaving with a DE safety razor and the learning curve is steep. Save the Feather blades and use them later once you get proficient.
  762. Very close shave and easy to use.
  763. great shave, way better than spending so much money on double blade refills
  764. This razor with personna platinum chrome blades make a great team, for me. Close shave no blood. It's very handy that I don't have to take it apart to change blades. Cleans easily. One reviewer said his rusted. I've had this one over a year with no rust yet, I shave rinse it that's it, no rust. I also have the wilkenson sword razor that I like, but it doesn't shave as close and I hafta take it apart to change blades.
  765. Good value that gives a great shave.
  766. The Feather Popular gives a fine shave. It is very mild. I like that it comes in a travel case. The razor is too light making it feel cheap. The handle is too long and too thin making it uncomfortable to hold. I bought it for a travel razor. I probably should have bought a Weishi instead as I find my old Gillette Super Speed a much better size and weight but don't want to travel with it.
  767. Easy to operate. Easy to clean. Much cheaper than multi blade razors, and cheaper too. Definitely recommend swtiching from the overpriced Gillette products.
  768. While it's a nice razor I went back to double edge disposables.
  769. Bought this to try out the Feather blades it came with before ordering a whole mess of them.<br /><br />This is my back up razor to my Merkur Heavy Duty Double Edge Razor #34C. Also comes with a nice hard plastic case so you could use this as your travel razor if needed.<br /><br />I really like this one too, long than the Merkur 34C, light and comfortable. I use it probably 2 x a week and the Merkur the rest of the time.<br /><br />This screws from underneath the head and opens up, drop blade in, and twist back the other way to close down on top of it.<br /><br />If you are looking to test out the feather blades and at the same time get a nice razor to go along with it, I would pick this up.
  770. I was expecting something a little more solid than what it is. I wasn't expecting it to be all plastic. It is good as a backup shaver if I strip the threads on my primary metal shaver.
  771. For my first razor of this type it works well. Keeps my face nice and tidy.
  772. Pretty mild razor, works best with feather blades. Light weight allows me to shave pretty fast. If you don't throw it around it won't break on you even though it's plastic. If it cuts you it's the technique, not the razor.
  773. This is my first Safety razor. I chose from a reputable name in the shaving industry. The handle is heavy black plastic with grip. Great product for the price. would recommend to first timers.<br /><br />Thanks
  774. Well made and well priced. If you're thinking about going DE buy this razor!<br /><br />The Feather brand blades are amazing for the price. Much cheaper than Gilette/Shick/BIC etc. My original blade has lasted about 2 months.
  775. Don't let the cheap price fool you .. This is a great razor of High quality seems like it will last a very long time.
  776. This was the second DE safety razor I purchased. Not an expert, Im in that experimental mode to see what I like. Figured this would be a great backup to my Edwin Jagger 89 that I could use for travel. I like the Feather blades, and took the gamble on this razor. It was a good bet. I like the geometry of this razor. Getting the right blade angle to my skin is 2nd nature with this razors's head. I have long thin fingers and find the handle more comfortable than the Edwin Jagger. This razor does not feel cheap, but feels practical and functional. The blade locks in tight and square.<br /><br />For me, this razor shines when there is only light beard growth to contend with as it is light weight. With heavier beard growth, the additional weight of an all metal razor head gives me slightly better control and smoother results.<br /><br />Otherwise, this is a great razor worthy of consideration.
  777. The razor handle and part of the body is made of plastics, but feels very solid and well-made. Have confidence that it will last!
  778. I'm new to wet shaving, and I initially only tried it to see if it would help with ingrown facial hairs. This razor helped sell me on the whole experience. I didn't want to spend a lot of money on something I wasn't sure would work, but I also didn't want to buy a cheap unbranded metal safety razor. I'd rather buy a mostly plastic item that is made in Japan by a surgical instrument company, than an unknown quality metal razor from China or the Middle East. As another reviewer mentioned, plastics and polymers are used with great success in high stress applications like guns, so I'm pretty sure they will do fine in a razor. I've been using disposable single blade bic razors for a while now, so this one actually felt quite substantial to me. The twist to open mechanism worked perfectly, and the lockup of the blade seemed solid.<br /><br />I ordered Astra super platinum blades for this razor. The Feather blades are known to be the sharpest available, and are not recommended for beginners. The razor and blades came before the other shaving equipment, so my first shave was with Barbesol. It was noticeably better than the shaves I'd been getting with Bic razors. The razor felt smoother and more comfortable, and I got a closer shave with a single pass. I was surprised to see that the razor did a MUCH better job of cutting the whiskers just below my nose. I was worried that the large head would make that problem area even harder to shave, but the angle you use with the safety razor puts the blade right up against the bottom of your nose. I'd been nicking my nostrils trying to get to that spot with the disposables, but with a safety razor there's no need to start your stroke that high in order to get a good cut there.<br /><br />Once my proraso and brush arrived I was able to whip up some proper shaving cream. The shave you get with real cream applied by a brush and a quality double edged razor blade is so much more comfortable than canned cream and disposable razors that I don't even care if it helps with ingrown hairs. This is my new routine. I picked up a styptic pen at Wal Mart, but despite my concerns I haven't gotten a single nick or &#34;weeper.&#34;<br /><br />If you look at the reviews you'll see consecutive 1 star ratings because this razor is &#34;too mild,&#34; and then &#34;too aggressive.&#34; I found it to be very mild, but shaving experiences are subjective. Perhaps the one who called it too aggressive was using the included Feather blades. Within a few days I started hunting vintage razors at local antique and thrift stores. I ended up finding a great condition 1958 Gillette Superspeed at a local shop for $18. If there's any reason not to buy this Feather razor, its if you find a vintage Superpeeisin good+ condition first at a comparable price. The Superspeed is a little slicker/smoother, just as comfortable, and shaves just a bit closer on the first pass. It is significantly heavier and much better looking than the Feather, but the Feather's long handle feels better in my big hands.<br /><br />One more thing that I'll add is that if I had it to do over again I'd buy a $17 premium boar hair brush instead of an $11 economy badger hair. I came across a vintage badger hair brush at an antique store for $6. It outperforms the new $11 one by a significant margin.
  779. Tired of exorbitant prices of cartridge systems, this was my foray into safety razors. Excellent, effortless shave since first shave :-)
  780. Coming from 2 all metal Merkur and Edwin Jagger which broke form a screw corrosion this Feather is like the cheap plastic disposable razor feel version.<br /><br />It reminds me of those throw away razors, but since I had lots of razors left over I wanted to try something in the butterfly opening versions.<br /><br />The mechanism is made from thin thin stainless, everything you see that is black is plastic. The lightweight actually seems to give me more feedback when rushing a shave during the shower.<br /><br />Its the kind you don't mind bringing on a trip incase you loose it.<br /><br />The Feather blades that it comes with are very sharp not bad, but works well with Derby blades too.
  781. I know that this razor isn't for everyone, but I really enjoy this one! I've had it for a few weeks now and I haven't had any issues with it. I was a little concerned about the weight at first, but the head of the razor is heavy enough that it only needs light pressure for removing hair. I have a pack of the Personna double-edge razors which are pretty good with this device. I haven't any nicks or cuts, save on where I went over an ingrown hair by accident. (My fault.) I use this razor with really hot water, an ordinary shave soap and Shave Secret shave oil and I consistently get a good shave every time. The two things I really like about the razor aside from the shave; the plastic handle and the loose tolerance for the locking mechanism ensures that it won't freeze shut over time. That is what happened to my last razor which was a Micro Touch Safety Razor. I liked that one two, but after almost a year, it refused to open. I don't see that happening with this one!
  782. This razor gives me the best shave I've ever had outside a barber shop bar none. No razor burn or face irritation whatsoever. I'm not very careful when I shave because I shave fast and no cuts. I'm not saying you can't cut yourself but you'll have to try pretty hard. I can't say enough about how well it shaves. I just wish they made it in an all metal model. Don't get me wrong because there is absolutely nothing wrong with it as it is but I wonder if it will pass the test of time being made of plastic. Oh well, at 14 bucks I can just buy me some spares. As a matter of fact, that's exactly what I'm going to do. Do your face a big favor and get one.
  783. I will never ever go back to expensive 3-5 blade razors these are the best shave you will get. You need to go a little slower but once you get the hang of it the time difference is less than 1 min longer than my old expensive razors. Just a word of caution, if you have any moles skin tags or just bumps this will fix that quick and painfully, so watch it.
  784. I haven't used a D/E shaver since I was 18 (45 years ago). The Feather razor is an excellent way to get reacquainted with a more retro shaving experience. Once I learned the proper techniques to use this cheapo device, my shaving experience became alot easier to deal with and cuts up my hairs like a ninja. Kind of like playing fruit ninja on my android, but without the irritation. The only con is that it looks like a cheap plastic kiddie toy...I probably mentioned that earlier.
  792. Definitely 'on the mild side,' but I knew when I bought it. It can be tricky to get a close shave out of this one, especially as your blade dulls, but fortunately, it comes with 5 light, sharp, and durable blades. UPDATE: This might not be the longest-lived handle out there, but that's the price one pays to pack light I suppose. A very 'safe' razor: I've only cut myself twice in several weeks, and that was because I didn't change the blade when I knew I should've. The razor handle itself is light and strong; I tend to expect plastics to discolor, feel 'cheap,' or start to crack, but I haven't had any problems with it thus far. It's excellent for travel; the plastic box it comes with is a little bulky, but a good place to store and pack it.
  793. This is a very mild shave that I use for sensitive areas. This is the cheapest razor you can buy that will cause the least irritation, but you should use another more aggressive razor in conjunction with this for a perfect shave. Construction is good and still has some heft to it even though a lot of it is made out of plastic. Very satisfied with this product.
  794. I'm a first time DE user and it was a pinch using this razor. You may have to shave twice to get your face smooth so this method of shaving isn't for the person in a rush. I'm glad that I bought this razor and started shaving this way.
  795. This is what is known as a great value - above average quality for the price paid (less than $12).<br /><br />The construction appears to be outstanding (very few things made in Japan are of poor quality, I think) and it functions well. This razor is much lighter weight than the normal all-metal DE (double edge) razors because of the plastic handle and guard. The enclosed Feather-brand blades work flawlessly and the lightweight plastic case will work well for traveling.<br /><br />I have smaller than average man hands (glove size 8) and the only improvement that I would suggest in the design of this razor is to make the standard-sized handle an inch longer. However, this does not detract from the value of this razor. While I have only owned this razor for a few days, I predict that it will last a very long time.<br /><br />As a final note, the butterfly-opening top is a much easier design for cleaning than the design where the top comes apart. I remove the blade and wipe it with the corner of a hand towel after rinsing it off (after shaving) as well as rinsing off the razor itself. I then lay the blade back in the open butterfly-style top for drying until I use it next. I have a coffee mug on my bathroom vanity where I place it so it stands upright to dry (and leans slightly to one side like a pencil in a coffee mug). I also use &#34;Shave Secret&#34; shaving oil (MUCH better than creams, gels, or soaps, in my opinion) so cleaning it after each use keep the excess shaving oil off of it as well. (I purchase the Shave Secret shaving oil at my local Walmart for $3.82 plus sales tax - that's cheaper than any online price including Amazon.)

  801. I've figured out why they don't really sell these anymore...newer disposable razor cartridges just do a better job.<br /><br />In my opinion, the modern multi-blade disposable shaving cartridge is right up there with inkjet printer cartridges (is it a &#34;cartridge&#34; thing...) as some of the MOST OVER PRICED items we purchase on a regular basis. When I saw that I can buy a 100 razors for this shaver for under $10 I though, &#34;What the heck, give it a try!&#34; I'm 51 and have been using a shaving brush and mug soap for years and wanted to go &#34;Mad Men&#34; with my razor and see how it worked for me.<br /><br />Plane & simple, the newer multi-blade razors just work better for me. I tried the Feather Razor for two-weeks and while it did an OK job, my Schick Quattro blades did a much better job with none of the nicks and cuts. After the first few tries with my Feather razor my neck looked like a war zone with numerous small cuts. After awhile I figured out the best angle to use the razor & how much pressure to apply to get a semi-close shave but reduce the cuts. I think this is where the modern multi-blades shine. The pivoting head keeps the blades at the correct angle and you can pretty much push as hard as you want (within reason) and still not cut your face. My goodness I sound like a TV commercial...<br /><br />The quality of this razor seems good and I really liked how clean the blade stayed. The only thing that I dislike about the modern multi-blade cartridge (except the price) is how clogged the blades get with hairs & soap. You just can't clean that stuff out of there.<br /><br />I'm going to keep using it every now & then to see if my skills improve. I think this is a solid model at a nice, &#34;Give it a try&#34; price. Good luck!
  802. Maybe the best choice that straddles the ground between a disposable and a double edged razor. Light weight, light price.
  803. I agree with most of the reviews here that this is basically an excellent razor for the money, but I have a problem with it.<br /><br />Perhaps I am the only one who has trouble gripping the razor but I often find the glossy plastic handle difficult to grip making fine control of the razor problematic. Perhaps it's just not a good match for those of us with a light touch. It is my only complaint with this specific razor. I've been using it for about a month now.<br /><br />In any event, I use it mostly on weekends. During the week I just want to get the job done and don't want to spend the extra time and care that double-edge razor shaving can require and so I often revert to more modern multi-blade shaving.   804. With the cost of my cartridge razor refills running $2.50 to $3 each, I decided to try a DE razor, but I didn't want to break the bank on my first one. The price is right on this one and after three weeks I can say this is a really great razor that is worth more than I paid for it. I only shave every two to three days and for me, shaving is all about just getting the scruff off my face; Comfort is my next priority, with closeness a distant third. This razor produces a comfortable shave even for a first-timer like me, without cutting up my face like my fancy Mach64 wonder-razor. I've got less razor burn and less discomfort after my shave. Since I don't care too much about a close shave it doesn't much matter to me that it doesn't shave quite as close as my cartridge razor. If you're willing to spend more time on your shave than I do it would likely shave just as close as you want it to. My only complaint - it's minor, considering I gave it five stars - is the material. I love plastic and it doesn't bother me that this razor is made of it, but it sure doesn't weigh much. Researching DE shaving before taking the plunge, I read a lot about \\"letting the weight of the razor do the work\\" and not putting pressure on the razor. Since this thing weighs next to nothing, there isn't much weight to do the work for me. I handle the razor with my fingertips and put very light pressure on the head while I shave. That works fine; it weighs and handles just about the same as my cartridge razor. Just be aware that it's very light and will handle differently than a metal razor. The Feather blades that come with it are excellent. Since I'll be paying about $.20 per blade, instead of 2 or 3 bucks, this razor will probably pay for itself, too. I would highly recommend this.

But, it is holding up strong for now, and the value is solid until it fails. Down the line, I want a 100% stainless safety razor but they cost a few hundred dollars. So, until then, I am one of the unwashed (but not unshaved) masses who has to make due.
  820. Being new to double-edge shaving, I’ve been reading for a few years all these rave reviews about how smooth & easy a shave you can get with these razors. With this Feather DE Razor, I have found this to be absolutely true, and I’m having the easiest & closest shaves I’ve ever had. I have a moderate to heavy beard and, with the Feather razor, I don’t have to push hard or repeat strokes to get a good shave. The extra-long handle balances nicely in the hand. And for all the talk about the plastic in the handle, the weight & feel suggests to me that the plastic covers a metal core of the handle. Anyway, it feels very solid. The razor comes with 2 Feather blades. Yes, the blades are very sharp, but also very smooth. Some of the reviews here talk about the Feather blades being “unforgiving” or prone to unexpected cutting. All I can say is that I’ve never cut myself with this razor. One more note about double-edge blades: I’ve found that if I thoroughly rinse the blade after every use, fully open the cutting head to let both razor & blade completely dry, and flip the blade over every time I shave—I can get a double-edge blade to last two months or longer! Anyway, this is a great razor, and super-economical to boot!
  821. I feel really, really bad for using those cheep throw-away razors for so long....waking up to the indignity of trying to get a close shave those cheap products. The countless nicks and cuts.<br /><br />Finally, I got fed up and bought the Feather Double Edge Razor. I am in absolute heaven. Not only is the shave close, the blades are good and stay sharp for 2-6 shaves. No more of trying to rinse the blade clean with that sticky glue the Gillette engineers use in the throw away blades. The shave is so close and with few cuts, my chin feels like a new born baby and I feel like a brand new man. I would recommend any man not to hesitate. Get rid of throw-aways. This takes shaving to a new level.<br /><br />You may also want to order extra replacement blades, so as to not run out. I ordered 50 for a reasonable price, which should last me 6 months.
